In the [[utilities]] industry, the '''Prudent Investment Rule''' refers to a series of state standards which determine the fiscal soundness of a utility in the course of rate recovery for recoverable capital costs to be determined by that state’s [[Public Utilities Commission|Public Service Commission]] (PSC). The determination is established through a series of filings from the utility to the PSC and hearings conducted by the PSC. This occurs during a prudency hearing.<ref>{{cite web|last=Zacher|first=Glenn|title=Prudency review required before deferred revenue can be recovered|url=http://www.stikeman.com/cps/rde/xchg/se-en/hs.xsl/14102.htm|accessdate=22 April 2014}}</ref> The PSC follows these standards to determine if the capital costs were a "prudent investment".<ref>{{cite web|title=Managing Risk: Prudency Reviews and Nuclear Projects|url=http://www.fortnightly.com/fortnightly/2006/02/managing-risk-prudence-reviews-and-nuclear-projects|publisher=Fortnightly|accessdate=16 April 2014}}</ref> To determine the prudency of the investment, the PSC applies the prudent investment test or standard, determining if the costs were reasonable at the time they were incurred, and given the circumstances and what was known or knowable at the time, are to be included in the firm's rates.<ref>{{cite book|last=Rose|first=Kenneth|title=Electric Power: Traditional Monopoly Franchise Regulation and Rate Making|year=2004|publisher=Elsevier Science & Technology|location=Oxford}}</ref> It is commonly used as an oversight tool by the government to ensure that money invested into a project is being spent as it was intended so the utility may recoup some costs in construction through a recovery in rates, hence the title prudent investment rule.<ref>{{cite web|title=Frequently Asked Questions FAQs|url=http://www.psc.sc.gov/Documents/Consumer%20Information/Frequently%20Asked%20Questions%20PDF%20For%20Website.pdf|publisher=Public Service Commission of South Carolina|accessdate=16 April 2014}}</ref> Regulators can consider cases of hidden imprudence, but are required to consider what was known or knowable at the time the decision was made by the PSC.<ref>{{cite book|last=Rose|first=Kenneth|title=Electric Power: Traditional Monopoly Franchise Regulation and Rate Making|year=2004|publisher=Elsevier Science & Technology|location=Oxford}}</ref>
The term Prudent Investment Rule, and the associated standards, have been established through a series of legal precedents. The first case to set precedent was the [[United States Supreme Court]] case of [[Munn v. Illinois]] in 1877, which allowed states to have a say in rates.<ref>{{cite web|title=Munn v. Illinois|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/supremecourt/text/94/113|publisher=Cornell University Law School|accessdate=16 April 2014}}</ref> Once the nature of recoverable capital costs was defined, a second question remained as to the rate at which that capital could be recovered. This issue was reasonably addressed in 1935 in Bluefield Water Works & Improvement Co. v. Public Service Commission of West Virginia, when the court said that a public utility is entitled to such rates as will permit it to earn a return equal to that generally being made at the same time and in the same general part of the country on investments in other business undertakings which are attended by corresponding risks and uncertainties.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bluefield Waterworks Improvement Company v. Public Service Commission of West Virginia|url=https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Bluefield_Waterworks_Improvement_Company_v._Public_Service_Commission_of_West_Virginia|publisher=WikiSource|accessdate=15 April 2014}}</ref>
==Advantages of Rate of Return Regulation with Prudent Investment Rule== [[Rate-of-return regulation|Rate-of-return Regulation]] is a system for setting the prices charged by government-regulated monopolies, such as utility companies. There are several advantages to using [[rate-of-return regulation]]. The first is that it is sustainable if there is no competition because prices can be adjusted to the company’s changing conditions. It can also provide comfort to investors because [[rate-of-return regulation]] constrains the regulator’s discretion in setting prices. This lowers investor risk, which lowers the cost of capital. Company profits can be kept within acceptable levels from the perspectives of both investors and customers. Unless the regulator chronically underestimates the cost of capital (and courts do not reverse the regulator in this regard), investors can be confident they have a fair opportunity to receive the profits they expect and thus are willing to make investments. Customers can observe that the regulator is limiting company profits to the cost of capital.<ref>{{cite book|title=Rate of Return: Regulation|year=1996|publisher=Mark A. Jamison Public Utility Research Center, University of Florida}}</ref>
==Disallowance== According to [[Oak Ridge National Laboratory]], there are five categories that plants under construction may fall into that keep them from being included in the rate base.<ref>{{cite web|title=Prudence Issues Affecting the U.S. Electric Utility Industry|url=http://web.ornl.gov/info/reports/1987/3445602684959.pdf}}</ref> # Imprudence: When a utility fails to show that it made prudent decisions in [[Public utilities commission|Public Service Commission]] hearings, then the facility being reviewed is [[disallow]]ed from the rate base. # [[Excess Capacity]]: Regardless of prudence, a plant recently constructed may not be included in the rate base if it is ruled to have a generating capacity that is in excess of what is needed by the ratepayers. Each jurisdiction will calculate excess capacity differently. This is not a permanent disallowance and if the need of the customer or ratepayer grows then the plant can again be included in the rate base. # Cost Caps: In rare cases the [[Public Utilities Commission]] will set a cap on construction costs for a new facility. If the plant is completed at a higher cost, then this excess cost may not be allowed in the rate base. # Economic Value: The actual economic value of the recently constructed plant may be found to be less than the construction costs. A plant under construction should be regularly evaluated to ensure that continued construction is in the best interest of the ratepayer. # Other: This category includes any other reason that a facility may be disallowed from the rate base. This includes canceled construction. If a plant is canceled then it is not “used and useful” and may be completely disallowed from the rate base or allowed to recover prudent costs with no return recovery on the balance or allowed to recover prudent costs with a recovery of the debt return from the unrecovered balance.

{{About||the full right and power of a governing body over itself|Sovereignty|the head of state in a monarchy|Monarch|other uses}} The word '''Sovereign''' is borrowed from [[Old French]] ''soverain'', which is ultimately derived from the [[Latin]] word ''superānus'', meaning "above". It is a title which can be given to people in various categories.
The roles of a sovereign vary from [[Monarch]] or [[Head of state]] to head of municipal government or head of a chivalric order. As a result, the word sovereign has more recently also come to mean independence or autonomy.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/sovereign|title=Definition of sovereign in English:}}</ref>
==Head of State== The word ''Sovereign'' is frequently used synonymously with [[Monarch]]. There are [[Royal and noble ranks#Sovereign|numerous titles]] in a monarchical rule which can belong to the sovereign. The sovereign is the autonomous head of the state. Examples of the various titles in modern sovereign leaders are:
{|class="wikitable" |- | Emperor|| [[Akihito]], Emperor of Japan|| Sultan || [[Hassanal Bolkiah]], Sultan of Brunei |- | King || [[Philippe of Belgium]]|| Pope || [[Pope Francis]], sovereign of the Vatican City State |- | Grand Duke || [[Henri, Grand Duke of Luxembourg]]|||| |- | Prince|| [[Albert II, Prince of Monaco]]|| Co-Prince|| [[Joan Enric Vives Sicília]], [[Co-Princes of Andorra|Co-Prince of Andorra]] |}
==Chivalric Orders== The term ''Sovereign'' is generally used in place of "Grand Master" for the supreme head of various orders [[Europe]]an nations. In the [[Sovereign Military Order of Malta]], the Grand Master is styled "Sovereign", e.g. Sovereign Grand Master, due to its status as an internationally independent sovereign entity. Examples of the Sovereign of a chivalric order are: * [[Philip the Good]], founder of the [[Order of the Golden Fleece]] * [[Karl von Habsburg]], current Sovereign of the [[Order of the Golden Fleece]] * [[Georg Friedrich, Prince of Prussia]], current Sovereign of the [[Order of Louise]] * [[Caroline of Baden]], Sovereign of the [[Order of Saint Elizabeth]] * [[Duarte Nuno, Duke of Braganza]], Sovereign of the [[Order of Saint Isabel]]
==Municipal Government== As chief officer of municipal government, ''the Sovereign'' had duties and responsibilities deriving from the charter which established the local town borough or council. This was commonly used throughout [[Ireland]]. This usage was less common in the [[United Kingdom]] and occasionally meant a [[Marcher Lord]].
===Characteristics=== The candidate for this position was elected by the freemen and burgesses of the town, borough and city councils and had to be a [[Burgess (title)|Burgess]] himself. And in later years he also had to be approved by the patron.<ref>{{cite book|title=Extracts from the Old Corporation Books of New Ross|jstor=25507115|publisher=The Journal of the Royal Society of Antiquaries of Ireland|date= 31 March 1901}}</ref><ref name="First report">{{cite book|title=FIRST REPORT OF THE COMMISSIONERS APPOINTED TO INQUIRE INTO THE MUNICIPAL CORPORATIONS IN IRELAND|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c9VbAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA917|year=1835|pages=917–}}</ref> The level of responsibility ranged from enacting by-laws about tolls up to the death penalty. Some charters established the sovereign as the local [[magistrate]] or [[Justice of the peace]]. The office generally had no salary though some patrons provided a stipend to the Sovereign in their borough.<ref name="First report"/> In some localities the sovereign was appointed directly by the patron of the borough which allowed him to influence the election of the local MP. Once the parliamentary franchise was lost with the [[Acts of Union 1800]], the role became largely ceremonial or forgotten.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Parliamentary Gazetteer of Ireland: Adapted to the New Poor-law, Franchise, Municipal and Ecclesiastical Arrangements, and Compiled with a Special Reference to the Lines of Railroad and Canal Communication, as Existing in 1814-45|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9rblf03SdkYC&pg=PA299|year=1846|publisher=A. Fullarton and Company|pages=299–}}</ref><ref name="Britain1840">{{cite book|author=Great Britain|title=The Statutes of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xJZFAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA650|year=1840|publisher=Her Majesty's Printers|pages=650–}}</ref>
The title of the chief officer of a city council has become known as a [[Mayor]]. In some municipal boroughs the titles Borough Master or [[Burgomaster]], [[Bailiff]], [[Portreeve]], [[wikt:warden|Warden]] and [[Provost (civil)|Provost]] were used interchangeably with mayor and sovereign.<ref name="Britain1840"/>
===History=== Ireland had established self-governing municipal boroughs which gave a city-state status to the locality in existence since the Norman conquest. These were most typically in the denser populated provinces of [[Munster]] and [[Leinster]]. The provision of the borough and the corporation was established through a charter, the granting of which was known as incorporation. Freemen and burgesses were the usual governing members of the council and elected their chief officer, the Sovereign. In earlier incarnations the council also managed the law court known as the "hundred court" and dealt with local administrative and legal business. Boroughs also elected the local MP. Positions on the council were predominantly from among the wealthy and related families in the area.<ref name="borough">{{cite web|url=https://www.historyireland.com/volume-21/irish-municipal-boroughs/|title=Irish Municipal boroughs}}</ref>
The first mention of the Sovereign in [[Kilkenny]] dates from 1231. The ''Liber Primus Kilkenniensis'' is a contemporaneously written account of the proceedings of Kilkenny municipality beginning in 1230 and running to 1538.<ref>{{Cite journal|jstor = 25513427|title = Notes on the Liber Primus Kilkenniensis|journal = The Journal of the Royal Society of Antiquaries of Ireland|volume = 17|issue = 1|pages = 21–38|last1 = McNeill|first1 = Charles|year = 1927}}</ref> Attempts have been made to identify the names of Kilkenny's sovereigns and currently there is a list of the names of 244 sovereigns from 1282 to 1608. At that point a new charter was established for the town and in 1609 the first Mayor of the City of Kilkenny is elected.<ref name="Kilkenny">{{cite web|url=http://www.kilkennycity.ie/eng/Your_Council/The_Sovereigns_and_Mayors_of_Kilkenny_1282-2003/|title=The sovereigns and Mayors of Kilkenny}}<</ref>
===Weakening power=== Early Irish borough had a city-state status however with the unification of Ireland under the crown in 1603 they were transformed into more ordinary municipal towns on the English model. Part of this was to reduce the autonomy of the Irish borough and partly to establish the new rules by which the planted towns of Ireland were to operate. Since the MPs to the Irish parliament were elected by the borough council, and to prevent a Catholic majority there, additional boroughs were created in areas with a strong Protestant base. A direct result of this was the Protestant majority of 232 to 100 in the 1613 House of Commons. The new charters placed the government of the borough with the Sovereign and twelve chief burgesses, who are to elect all the rest and stipulated that all had to conform to the established church by taking the Oath of Supremacy.<ref name="gerrymander">{{cite web|url=https://www.historyireland.com/early-modern-history-1500-1700/the-greatest-gerrymander-in-irish-history-james-is-40-boroughs-of-1612-13/|title=New Boroughs}}</ref><ref name="Lewis1995">{{cite book|author=Samuel Lewis|title=A Topographical Dictionary of Ireland: Comprising the Several Counties, Cities, Boroughs, Corporate, Market, and Post Towns, Parishes, and Villages, with Historical and Statistical Descriptions ...|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oh_xz5nqbyQC&pg=PA461|year=1995|publisher=Genealogical Publishing Com|isbn=978-0-8063-1063-3|pages=461–}}</ref><ref name="MerewetherStephens1835">{{cite book|author1=Henry Alworth Merewether|author2=Archibald John Stephens|title=The history of the Boroughs and municipal Corporations of the United Kingdom|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ae89AAAAcAAJ&pg=PA1620|year=1835|publisher=Stevens, Yard|pages=1620–}}</ref>
[[Sir John Davies]], [[Attorney General for Ireland]] wrote "the newly erected boroughs . . . will be perpetual seminaries of Protestant burgesses".<ref name="gerrymander"/>
Historically the number of boroughs varied considerably. There were 117 boroughs in Ireland from 1685 to 1800. Prior to the passing of the [[Municipal Corporations Act 1835]], there were sixty-eight borough corporations in Ireland.<ref name="gerrymander"/> As each of the changes and new charters were brought in and with the loss of the parliamentary franchise, sovereigns became less powerful and more ceremonial.
===Legacy=== There is a sailing race held in [[Kinsale]] which references back to the chief officer of the town council. When looking to name a new trophy the local yacht club discovered that the ‘Sovereign of Kinsale’ used to put up a trophy for a sailing race in the late 1700s.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pressreader.com/ireland/irish-examiner-supplement/20170610|title= Sovereign's cup 2017|newspaper=Irish Examiner Supplement|date= 10 June 2017}}</ref> The result is that the race and trophy today is known as The Sovereign's cup.<ref>https://www.sovereignscup.com/sovereigns-cup-kinsale/Event-Info</ref> Kinsale had been given its charter to set up a borough led by a Sovereign around 1319.<ref name="Lewis1995"/>
==See also== {{wiktionary}} * [[Mayor]] * [[Borough]] * [[Municipal borough]] * [[Bailiff]] * [[Portreeve]] * [[Warden (disambiguation)|Warden]] * [[Provost (civil)|Provost]] * [[Burgomaster]]

Küchler]] | editing = [[Elliot Graham]] | distributor = [[Universal Studios|Universal Pictures]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://time.com/3604784/steve-jobs-movie-universal/ |title=Steve Jobs Movie Scooped Up by Universal |last=Luckerson |first=Victor |work=Time |date=November 25, 2014 |accessdate=December 29, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303165719/http://time.com/3604784/steve-jobs-movie-universal/ |archive-date=March 3, 2016 |dead-url=no}}</ref> | released = {{Film date|2015|09|05|[[Telluride Film Festival|Telluride]]|2015|10|09|United States|2015|11|13|United Kingdom}}<!--FIRST RELEASE DATE TO PUBLIC, NOT WIDE--> | runtime = 122 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 123--><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/steve-jobs-film |title=STEVE JOBS |publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]] |date=October 8, 2015 |accessdate=August 18, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305205050/http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/steve-jobs-film |archive-date=March 5, 2016 |dead-url=no}}</ref> | country = {{plainlist| * United Kingdom * United States }} | language = English | budget = $30 million<ref name="BOM" /> | gross = $34.4 million<ref name="BOM">{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=jobs2015.htm |title=Steve Jobs (2015) |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=February 23, 2016 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.boxofficemojo.com%2Fmovies%2F%3Fid%3Djobs2015.htm&date=2016-09-04 |archive-date=2016-09-04 |dead-url=no}}</ref> | production companies = {{Plainlist| * [[Legendary Entertainment|Legendary Pictures]] * [[Scott Rudin Productions]] * [[The Mark Gordon Company]] * Decibel Films * [[Cloud Eight Films]] }} }}
'''''Steve Jobs''''' is a 2015 [[Biographical film|biographical]] [[drama (film and television)|drama]] film directed by [[Danny Boyle]] and written by [[Aaron Sorkin]]. Adapted from the [[Steve Jobs (book)|2011 book of the same name]] by [[Walter Isaacson]] as well as interviews conducted by Sorkin, the film is structured into three acts which cover 14 years (1984–1998) in the life of [[microcomputer revolution|personal computing]] [[innovator]] and [[Apple Inc.]] co-founder [[Steve Jobs]], with each act taking place immediately prior to the launch of a key product – the [[Macintosh 128K|Apple Macintosh]], the [[NeXT Computer]] and the [[iMac G3|iMac]]. Jobs is portrayed by [[Michael Fassbender]], with [[Kate Winslet]], [[Seth Rogen]], [[Katherine Waterston]], [[Michael Stuhlbarg]], and [[Jeff Daniels]] in supporting roles.
Development on the project began in 2011 after the rights to Isaacson's book were acquired. Sorkin wrote the screenplay and filming began in January 2015. A variety of actors were considered and cast before Fassbender eventually took the role. Editing was extensive on the project, with editor [[Elliot Graham]] noting that he was working on existing footage while the film was still shooting. [[Daniel Pemberton]] served as the film's composer, with a focus dedicated to dividing the score into three distinguishable sections.
''Steve Jobs'' premiered at the [[Telluride Film Festival|2015 Telluride Film Festival]] on September 5, 2015, and began a [[limited release]] in [[New York City]] and [[Los Angeles]] on October 9, 2015. It opened nationwide in the U.S. on October 23, 2015, to critical acclaim. Individuals close to Jobs such as [[Steve Wozniak]] and [[John Sculley]] would praise the film's performances, but the film also received criticisms for its inaccuracy in some of its scenes. Winslet won a [[Golden Globe Award|Golden Globe]] and a [[British Academy Film Awards|BAFTA Award]] for Best Supporting Actress and Sorkin won the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Screenplay]] at the [[73rd Golden Globes]], while Fassbender and Winslet received nominations for [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]] and [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]], respectively, at the [[88th Academy Awards]].
== Plot == <!-- Per WP:FILMPLOT, plot summaries for featured films are set between 400-700 words. -->In 1984, the [[Macintosh 128K|Apple Macintosh 128K]]'s voice demo fails less than an hour before its unveiling at [[De Anza College|Flint Center]]. [[Apple, Inc.|Apple]] co-founder [[Steve Jobs]] demands engineer [[Andy Hertzfeld]] fix it, threatening to publicly implicate him in the presentation's credits if he does not. Hertzfeld finally suggests faking the demo using the prototype [[Macintosh 512K]] computer.
Jobs rants to marketing executive [[Joanna Hoffman]] about a ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine article exposing his paternity dispute with ex-girlfriend [[Chrisann Brennan]] – he denies he is the father of Brennan's five-year-old daughter, [[Lisa Brennan-Jobs|Lisa]]. Brennan arrives with Lisa to confront him – she is bitter over his denials and his refusal to support her despite his wealth. Jobs bonds with Lisa over her [[MacPaint]] art and agrees to provide more money and a house. Apple co-founder [[Steve Wozniak]] asks Jobs to acknowledge the [[Apple II]] team in his presentation, but Jobs feels that mentioning the computer (which he considers obsolete) is unwise.
By 1988, following the apparent failure of the Macintosh, Jobs has founded a new company, [[NeXT]]. Before the [[NeXT Computer]] launch at the [[War Memorial Opera House]], he spends time with 9-year-old Lisa, but his relationship with Brennan is still strained – he accuses her of irresponsible behavior and of using Lisa to get money from him. Wozniak arrives and predicts the NeXT will be another failure. Jobs confronts him about his public criticism of him, and Wozniak questions Jobs' contributions to computing history. Jobs defends his role as that of a conductor, who directs "musicians" like Wozniak.
Apple CEO [[John Sculley]] demands to know why the world believes he fired Jobs – Jobs was actually forced out by the Apple board, who were resolute on updating the Apple II following the Macintosh's lackluster sales. Jobs lambasted the decision and dared them to cast a final vote on his tenure, despite Sculley's warnings. After Hoffman and Jobs discuss NeXT's unclear direction, she realizes that Jobs has designed the computer to entice Apple to buy the company and reinstate him.
By 1998, Apple has fired Sculley, purchased NeXT, and named Jobs CEO, and Jobs is about to unveil the [[iMac G3|iMac]] at [[Louise M. Davies Symphony Hall|Davies Symphony Hall]]. He is delighted by Hoffman's strong commercial forecasts, but furious that Lisa has allowed her mother to sell the house Jobs bought for them. Hoffman reminds Jobs that he threatened to withhold Lisa's college tuition – Hertzfeld admits that he paid Lisa's tuition and suggested she attend therapy. Wozniak again asks that Jobs credit the Apple II team during the presentation, and again he refuses.
Sculley arrives in secret and the two make amends. Jobs and Sculley discuss Jobs' life as an adopted child, and Jobs admits that his need for control stems from his feelings of powerlessness in being given up. At the behest of Hoffman, Jobs apologizes to Lisa for his mistakes and accepts that he is her father, admitting that he is "poorly made". Lisa watches her father take the stage to introduce the iMac.
== Cast == * [[Michael Fassbender]] as [[Steve Jobs]]: :Co-founder of [[Apple Inc.]]<ref name="cast">{{cite web |url=http://www.cultofmac.com/310397/meet-official-cast-steve-jobs-movie/ |title=Meet the official cast of the Steve Jobs movie |accessdate=July 12, 2015 |last=Hein |first=Buster |date=January 28, 2015 |work=Cultofmac |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160317052105/http://www.cultofmac.com/310397/meet-official-cast-steve-jobs-movie/ |archive-date=March 17, 2016 |dead-url=no}}</ref> Fassbender acknowledged his lack of physical resemblance to Jobs, but stated that he was more interested in capturing Jobs' essence than his appearance. In regards to how he aimed to depict Jobs, Fassbender stated he aimed to depict Jobs as a "somebody who was passionate about his vision" as opposed to a cruel person.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2015/10/12/michael-fassbender-steve-jobs-interview/73601092/ |first=Bryan |last=Alexander |title=Michael Fassbender portrays 'poorly made' Steve Jobs |date=October 12, 2015 |work=USA TODAY |accessdate=August 18, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160111020933/http://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2015/10/12/michael-fassbender-steve-jobs-interview/73601092/ |archive-date=January 11, 2016 |dead-url=no}}</ref> * [[Kate Winslet]] as [[Joanna Hoffman]]: :Apple and [[NeXT]] marketing executive and Jobs' confidant in the film.<ref name="cast" /> When discussing her audition for the film, Winslet later commented that she "heard about it through a crew member who I happened to be working with [in Australia on ''[[The Dressmaker (2015 film)|The Dressmaker]]''], I didn't even care what role it was. I just wanted to be in it. Found out the nature of the role. Googled [Hoffman]. Found one picture of her. Got my husband to go to a wig shop. Buy a short-haired dark wig. Stuck it on my head. Sent a photograph of myself to [producer] Scott Rudin. Danny Boyle came to Melbourne and we had a meeting and he gave me the part."<ref name="Labrecque" /> Winslet spent considerable time with [[Joanna Hoffman]] to prepare for the role before production began. She noted that Hoffman "has a softness to her. She came to America as a young woman and achieved a great deal. One thing that was unique about her as a figure in Steve's life was that she didn't need anything from him. She just needed for him to be the best version of himself. And that's what really set their relationship apart from any relationship with all his other colleagues."<ref name="hoffman">{{cite web |url=http://www.vulture.com/2015/08/kate-winslet-on-her-role-in-steve-jobs.html |title=How Kate Winslet Won a Role in Steve Jobs and Managed All That Sorkin Dialogue |accessdate=August 26, 2016 |last=Kachka |first=Boris |date=August 26, 2015 |work=Vulture |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160618180609/http://www.vulture.com/2015/08/kate-winslet-on-her-role-in-steve-jobs.html |archive-date=June 18, 2016 |dead-url=no}}</ref> Winslet credits Hoffman's difficult childhood (that began in Armenia) with her ability to manage Jobs.<ref name="dbprem" /> {{paragraph break}} On the nature of the relationship between Hoffman and Jobs, Winslet said that she and Fassbender "were able to develop as literally co-workers. I do believe it was very similar to the relationship that Steve and Joanna had. She was like his work wife. She was head of marketing for the Macintosh, and then she stayed with him for his working life. She was an extraordinary, feisty Eastern European person who was pretty much the only person who could actually knock sense into Steve, and she was also kind of an emotional compass." In developing her sense of the character, Winslet stated that she "just wanted to please [Hoffman] as much as I could. How she sounds, and her accent, is fairly complicated. She grew up largely in Armenia, spent some time in Poland, and has Russians in her family, so she has all three accents, but she's been in America since she was a teenager, so she had American rhythms. You know, she really has this accent that goes way up and down. It's almost impossible to copy because of just how singsongy it becomes. So I had to put it into my own register. But we were all doing accents. I mean, Michael's Irish, and he's playing Steve Jobs, for God's sake."<ref name=hoffman/> Finally, Winslet notes that Hoffman "did genuinely love [Jobs]. And spending time with her, when I was figuring out how to play this difficult part, she would become very emotional. She misses him terribly."<ref name="dbprem"/> * [[Seth Rogen]] as [[Steve Wozniak]]: :Co-founder of Apple and creator of the [[Apple II]].<ref name="cast"/> Rogen admitted to not being familiar with Wozniak, let alone knowing he was co-founder of Apple. He met with Wozniak to prepare for the film, specifically picking up his tendency to move his hands around while speaking.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.gq.com/story/steve-jobs-seth-rogen-qa |first=Lauren |last=Larson |title=Seth Rogen on Steve Jobs and Why He Has Mixed Feelings About Biopics |date=October 16, 2015 |work=GQ |accessdate=March 29, 2017 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.gq.com%2Fstory%2Fsteve-jobs-seth-rogen-qa&date=2017-03-29 |archive-date=March 29, 2017 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref name="BBCwozint">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-31463351 |title=Woz on watches, addiction and being played by Seth Rogen |accessdate=February 15, 2015 |last=Lobel |first=Mark |date=February 15, 2015 |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.com%2Fnews%2Ftechnology-31463351&date=2016-09-04 |archive-date=2016-09-04 |dead-url=no}}</ref> In regards to Wozniak's relationship with Jobs, Rogen stated that "his feelings towards Jobs were very complex and interesting. Part of it was taking it at face value and part was reading between the lines."<ref name="dbprem" /> Wozniak stated that he felt honored to be portrayed by Rogen in the film.<ref name="anyway" /> * [[Jeff Daniels]] as [[John Sculley]], CEO of Apple from 1983 to 1993<ref name="cast"/> * [[Katherine Waterston]] as [[Chrisann Brennan]], Jobs' former girlfriend and Lisa's mother * [[Michael Stuhlbarg]] as [[Andy Hertzfeld]], a member of the [[Macintosh 128K|original Mac]] team * Makenzie Moss, Ripley Sobo, and [[Perla Haney-Jardine]] as [[Lisa Brennan-Jobs]], Jobs' daughter (depicted her at different ages throughout the film) * [[Sarah Snook]] as [[Andrea Cunningham|Andrea "Andy" Cunningham]], manager of the Macintosh and [[iMac G3|iMac]] launches * Adam Shapiro as [[Avie Tevanian]], software engineer for NeXT and later Apple * [[John Ortiz]] as Joel Pforzheimer, a journalist for ''[[GQ]]'' who interviews Jobs throughout the film<ref name="cast"/>

To distinguish each of the three product launches depicted in the movie, Danny Boyle and cinematographer [[Alwin H. Küchler|Alwin Küchler]] implemented three different film formats: [[16mm film|16mm]] for 1984, [[35 mm film|35mm]] for 1988, and [[Digital cinematography|digital]] for 1998. They also wanted each of the film's three time periods to visually reflect Jobs' own development at the time. For instance, Küchler explains that the filming at [[De Anza College|Flint Center, De Anza college]] for the first act combined the graininess of 16 mm film and setting to accentuate a provisional, spontaneous look – much in the vein of how Jobs is portrayed at that time. The third act, shot with an [[Arri Alexa]] at the [[Davies Symphony Hall]], incorporated an aesthetic and color palette that were intended to be representative of Jobs' own design philosophies of the [[iMac]] and subsequent [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] hardware. Küchler describes his experience filming ''Steve Jobs'' as "brilliant and challenging at the same time", and that the goal was to "make sure that the visuals kept up with the words", in reference to the production's collaboration between Boyle and Sorkin.<ref name="boylewired">{{cite web |url=https://www.wired.com/2015/10/steve-jobs-danny-boyle-interview/ |title=Why Danny Boyle Filmed Steve Jobs in Three Different Formats |work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |date=October 16, 2015 |accessdate=November 17, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.wired.com%2F2015%2F10%2Fsteve-jobs-danny-boyle-interview%2F&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=September 3, 2016 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref name="kuchlerthalo">{{cite web |url=http://www.thalo.com/articles/view/1143/steve_jobs_dp_alwin_h_kchler_shoots_in_three_acts |title=Steve Jobs DP Alwin H. Costume designer [[Suttirat Anne Larlarb]] says the real Jobs never wore his trademark turtleneck jumper at any of the launches: "The turtleneck was the off book decision. In those 3 actual launches, in real life, he never wore that. In the 1998 portion of the film, in real life he was wearing a dark greyish/brownish suit. We made it for him as a back up idea in case we needed to adhere to it. As we got closer to the time of filming, I thought we'd set up rules for 1984, we'd set up rules for 1988 – there's so much of the film that's about design and he was about design."<ref name="filmdoctor">{{cite web|url=http://filmdoctor.co.uk/2015/12/01/steve-jobs-costume-designer-suttirat-larlarb-in-conversation|title=''Steve Jobs'' costume designer in conversation|website=filmdoctor.co.uk|date=December 1, 2015|accessdate=December 1, 2015|archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Ffilmdoctor.co.uk%2F2015%2F12%2F01%2Fsteve-jobs-costume-designer-suttirat-larlarb-in-conversation&date=2016-09-03|archive-date=September 3, 2016|dead-url=no}}</ref> Fassbender also remarked that the historically inaccurate black turtleneck for the third act was intentional, believing that wearing the attire "felt like I had arrived at [Steve Jobs'] vision, that the person had arrived." Fassbender later added that he and [[Danny Boyle]] decided on this look during filming, and wanted to "give the audience kind of a payoff."<ref name="fassbenderhuman">{{cite web |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/01/05/how-michael-fassbender-made-steve-jobs-human.html |title=How Michael Fassbender Made Steve Jobs Human |first=Kevin |last=Fallon |work=[[Daily Beast]] |date=January 5, 2016 |accessdate=January 5, 2016 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.thedailybeast.com%2Farticles%2F2016%2F01%2F05%2Fhow-michael-fassbender-made-steve-jobs-human.html&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=September 3, 2016 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref name="fassbenderpayoff">{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2016/film/awards/michael-fassbender-portraying-steve-jobs-1201701595/ |title=Michael Fassbender on Finding the Essence of ''Steve Jobs''|first=Jenelle |last=Riley |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=February 11, 2016 |accessdate=February 17, 2016 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fvariety.com%2F2016%2Ffilm%2Fawards%2Fmichael-fassbender-portraying-steve-jobs-1201701595%2F&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=September 3, 2016 |dead-url=no}}</ref>
=== Post-production === London-based studio Union created the film's [[visual effects]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Rosser |first=Michael |url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/union-to-handle-vfx-on-danny-boyles-steve-jobs-biopic/5083638.article?blocktitle=Most-popular&contentID=-1 |title=Union to handle VFX on Danny Boyle's Steve Jobs biopic |work=[[Screen International|ScreenDaily.com]] |date=February 26, 2015 |accessdate=March 3, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6kE6YBsof?url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/union-to-handle-vfx-on-danny-boyles-steve-jobs-biopic/5083638.article?blocktitle=Most-popular&contentID=-1 |archive-date=September 2, 2016 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> According to editor [[Elliot Graham]], extensive film editing took place even before principal photography was completed. During the one-week rehearsal that took place in between production for each of the three acts (shot in chronological order), Graham would work on the existing footage and receive ongoing feedback from Boyle in the editing room. In an interview with ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', Graham said a particular challenge for him was balancing the [[Shot (filmmaking)#Film editing|shot frequency]] and providing enough "visual interventions" to control for Sorkin's dialogue-heavy screenplay. He described approaching each scene as "a series of fight sequences". Michael Fassbender provided multiple versions of his performance as Jobs, which Graham and Boyle would then choose from during [[post-production]].<ref name="boylecrave">{{cite web |url=http://www.craveonline.com/culture/912765-interview-danny-boyle-politics-steve-jobs |title=Interview Danny Boyle on the Politics of ''Steve Jobs''|last=Bibbiani |first=William |work=[[CraveOnline]] |date=October 16, 2015 |accessdate=November 17, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.craveonline.com%2Fculture%2F912765-interview-danny-boyle-politics-steve-jobs&date=2016-09-02 |archive-date=2016-09-02 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref name="grahamguild">{{cite web |url=https://www.editorsguild.com/FromTheGuild.cfm?FromTheGuildid=535 |title=From the Guild: Getting to the Core of Apple |last=Feld |first=Rob |publisher=[[Motion Picture Editors Guild]] |date=November 4, 2015 |accessdate=November 17, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.editorsguild.com%2FFromTheGuild.cfm%3FFromTheGuildid%3D535&date=2016-09-02 |archive-date=2016-09-02 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/video/steve-jobs-editing-aaron-sorkin/ |title=Steve Jobs Editor on the Rush of Working With Aaron Sorkin Dialogue |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |accessdate=November 17, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fvariety.com%2Fvideo%2Fsteve-jobs-editing-aaron-sorkin%2F&date=2016-09-02 |archive-date=2016-09-02 |dead-url=no}}</ref> Graham also said: "Danny would be involved a lot but also take time away. He would say 'if I'm with you the whole time, we'll always have the same opinions because we're on the exact same journey.'"<ref name="FilmDoctor">{{cite web|url=http://filmdoctor.co.uk/2015/12/08/steve-jobs-editor-elliot-graham-in-conversation/|title=''Steve Jobs'' Elliot Graham in conversation|last=Wooding|first=Andy|website=filmdoctor.co.uk|date=December 8, 2015|accessdate=December 8, 2015|archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Ffilmdoctor.co.uk%2F2015%2F12%2F08%2Fsteve-jobs-editor-elliot-graham-in-conversation%2F&date=2016-09-02|archive-date=2016-09-02|dead-url=no}}</ref>

(film)|The Man from U.N.C.L.E.]] | prev_year = 2015 | next_title = | next_year = }} [[Daniel Pemberton]] composed the music for the film. Much like the film's visual approach, the score is divided into three distinguishable sections, each corresponding to the intended feel of the act in which the section is heard. "You have the first act which is analog," Pemberton explains, "you have the second act which is orchestral, and you have the third act which is digital." For the first act's composition, Pemberton primarily used analog synthesizers, in particular ones released no later than 1984 – the time the first act takes place – such as the [[Roland SH-1000]] and [[Yamaha CS-80]]. The second act's score is more operatic in nature, matching the setting of the [[War Memorial Opera House|San Francisco Opera House]]. Finally, the third act featured a more introspective score produced entirely digitally to complement its backdrop of the 1998 iMac product launch, and Pemberton correspondingly used his own iMac to compose this section.<ref name="pembertonpop">{{cite web |url=http://www.popmatters.com/feature/a-symphony-in-three-parts-breaking-down-the-steve-jobs-score-with-composer-/ |title=Breaking Down the == Release == ''Steve Jobs'' premiered at the [[Telluride Film Festival|2015 Telluride Film Festival]] on September 5, 2015,<ref name=prvar>{{cite news |url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/jobs-michael-fassbender-new-york-film-festival-1201549347/ |title=''Steve Jobs'' Starring Michael Fassbender to Screen at New York Film Festival |work=Variety |date=July 1, 2015 |first=Ramin |last=Setoodeh |accessdate=July 27, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fvariety.com%2F2015%2Ffilm%2Fnews%2Fjobs-michael-fassbender-new-york-film-festival-1201549347%2F&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=2016-09-03 |dead-url=no}}</ref> and began a [[limited release]] in [[New York City]] and [[Los Angeles]] on October 9, 2015. It opened [[Wide release|nationwide]] in the U.S. on October 23, 2015.<ref name=early>{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/universal-s-steve-jobs-release-822408 |title=Universal's ''Steve Jobs'' to Release Early in New York, Los Angeles |last=Washington |first=Arlene |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=September 11, 2015 |accessdate=September 12, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.hollywoodreporter.com%2Fnews%2Funiversal-s-steve-jobs-release-822408&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=2016-09-03 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref name=tweeks>{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/universal-tweaks-steve-jobs-release-1201591040/ |title=Universal Tweaks ''Steve Jobs'' Release |last=McNary |first=Dave |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=September 11, 2015 |accessdate=September 12, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fvariety.com%2F2015%2Ffilm%2Fnews%2Funiversal-tweaks-steve-jobs-release-1201591040%2F&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=2016-09-03 |dead-url=no}}</ref> The movie also served as the closing film for the 2015 [[BFI London Film Festival#2015|BFI London Film Festival]], approximately one month before its release in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] on November 13, 2015.<ref name="bficlose">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-34544465 |title=Steve Jobs stars Fassbender and Winslet bring London Film Festival to a close |first=Tim |last=Masters |work=[[BBC News]] |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=October 18, 2015 |accessdate=November 21, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.com%2Fnews%2Fentertainment-arts-34544465&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=2016-09-03 |dead-url=no}}</ref>
''Steve Jobs'' was released digitally on February 2, 2016 and was released on Blu-ray and DVD on February 16, 2016, and includes [[Audio commentary|feature commentary]] from Boyle, Sorkin, and [[Elliot Graham]]. The physical releases contain a 44-minute [[making-of documentary]], ''Inside Jobs: The Making of Steve Jobs'', chronicling the production of the film.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/from-universal-pictures-home-entertainment-steve-jobs-300192869.html |title=From Universal Pictures Home Entertainment: Steve Jobs |agency=[[PR Newswire]] |date=December 15, 2015 |accessdate=December 30, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151219004802/http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/from-universal-pictures-home-entertainment-steve-jobs-300192869.html |archive-date=2015-12-19 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://appleinsider.com/articles/15/12/16/danny-boyles-steve-jobs-biopic-set-for-feb-2-digital-release-later-on-blu-ray-dvd |title=Danny Boyle's Steve Jobs biopic set for Feb. 2 digital release, later on Blu-ray & DVD |first=Roger |last=Fingas |work=[[Apple Insider]] |date=December 16, 2015 |accessdate=December 30, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fappleinsider.com%2Farticles%2F15%2F12%2F16%2Fdanny-boyles-steve-jobs-biopic-set-for-feb-2-digital-release-later-on-blu-ray-dvd&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=2016-09-03 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/steve-jobs-inside-jobs-making-steve-jobs-video |title=STEVE JOBS – INSIDE JOBS: THE MAKING OF STEVE JOBS [Additional Material,Blu-ray] |publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]] |accessdate=December 30, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbfc.co.uk%2Freleases%2Fsteve-jobs-inside-jobs-making-steve-jobs-video&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=2016-09-03 |dead-url=no}}</ref>
== Reception ==
=== Box office === ''Steve Jobs'' grossed $17.8 million in North America and $16.7 million in other territories for a worldwide total of $34.4 million, against a budget of $30 million.<ref name=BOM />
In its opening weekend in limited release, the film grossed $521,000 from four theaters, for a per theater average of $130,250, beating out ''[[Sicario (2015 film)|Sicario]]'' ($67,000) for the best average theater gross of 2015.<ref name="Limited">{{cite web |last=D'Alessandro |first=Anthony |url=http://deadline.com/2015/10/martian-pan-the-walk-weekend-box-office-1201572119/ |title='Martian' Still Has Fuel In Its Second Frame; 'Pan' Walks Plank; 'Steve Jobs' Popular In NY & LA – Monday Postmortem |work=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=October 12, 2015 |accessdate=November 1, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fdeadline.com%2F2015%2F10%2Fmartian-pan-the-walk-weekend-box-office-1201572119%2F&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=2016-09-03 |dead-url=no}}</ref> The film began its wide release on October 23, 2015, alongside ''[[The Last Witch Hunter]]'', ''[[Paranormal Activity: The Ghost Dimension]]'', ''[[Rock the Kasbah (film)|Rock the Kasbah]]'', and ''[[Jem and the Holograms (film)|Jem and the Holograms]]''. In its opening weekend, the film was originally projected to gross $11–12 million from 2,491 theaters; however, after grossing just $2.5 million on its first day, it was revised to $7.4 million. It ended up grossing $7.1 million, finishing seventh at the box office.<ref name="opening">{{cite web |last=D'Alessandro |first=Anthony |url=http://deadline.com/2015/10/the-last-witch-hunter-paranormal-activity-goosebumps-box-office-preview-1201589142/ |title=Only ''Goosebumps'' Will Prevail In Five-Pic Logjam – Box Office Preview |work=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=October 20, 2015 |accessdate=November 1, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fdeadline.com%2F2015%2F10%2Fthe-last-witch-hunter-paranormal-activity-goosebumps-box-office-preview-1201589142%2F&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=2016-09-03 |dead-url=no}}</ref>
On November 10, 2015, just over two weeks after its wide release, Universal pulled the film from 2,072 theaters in the United States.<ref name="usbopulled">{{cite web |url=http://metro.co.uk/2015/11/11/steve-jobs-movie-pulled-from-over-2000-cinemas-in-us-after-flopping-at-box-office-5493699/ |title=Steve Jobs movie pulled from over 2,000 cinemas in US after flopping at box office |first=Caroline |last=Westbrook |work=[[Metro (magazine)|Metro]] |date=November 11, 2015 |accessdate=November 17, 2015 === Critical response === {{Multiple image|total_width=270 |image1=Michael Fassbender by Gage Skidmore 2015.jpg|width1=1446|height1=1962 |image2=KateWinsletByAndreaRaffin2011.jpg|width2=529|height2=669 |footer=Fassbender and Winslet received critical acclaim for their performances as Jobs and Hoffman, respectively.}} On the review aggregator [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an approval rating of 86%, based on 282 reviews, with an average rating of 7.6/10. The website's critical consensus reads: "Like the tech giant co-founded by its subject, ''Steve Jobs'' gathers brilliant people to deliver a product whose elegance belies the intricate complexities at its core."<ref name=RT>{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/steve_jobs_2015/ |title=Steve Jobs (2015) |publisher=[[Fandango Media]] |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=April 16, 2018 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.rottentomatoes.com%2Fm%2Fsteve_jobs_2015%2F&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=2016-09-03 |dead-url=no}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a [[weighted average]] score of 82 out of 100, based on 45 reviews, indicating "universal acclaim."<ref name=met>{{cite web |title=Steve Jobs Reviews |url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/steve-jobs |work=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=November 9, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.metacritic.com%2Fmovie%2Fsteve-jobs&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=2016-09-03 |dead-url=no}}</ref> According to [[CinemaScore]], audiences gave the film an average grade of "A-" on an A+ to F scale.<ref name="opening" />
[[Todd McCarthy]] of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' said Boyle's "electric" direction "temperamentally complements Sorkin's highly theatrical three-act study" and praised Fassbender in the role, who "doesn't closely physically resemble the man, [yet] he fully delivers the essentials of how we have come to perceive the man."<ref name=hrrev>{{cite web |last=McCarthy |first=Todd |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movie/steve-jobs/review/820561 |title='Steve Jobs': Telluride Review |accessdate=September 6, 2015 |date=September 6, 2015 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.hollywoodreporter.com%2Fmovie%2Fsteve-jobs%2Freview%2F820561&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=2016-09-03 |dead-url=no}}</ref> Justin Chang of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' extolled the film as "a wildly creative fantasia...a brilliant, maddening, ingeniously designed and monstrously self-aggrandizing movie."<ref name="variety">{{cite news |title=Telluride Film Review: ''Steve Jobs''|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/festivals/steve-jobs-review-michael-fassbender-telluride-film-festival-1201586996/ |last=Chang |first=Justin |date=September 6, 2015 |accessdate=September 6, 2015 |work=Variety |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fvariety.com%2F2015%2Ffilm%2Ffestivals%2Fsteve-jobs-review-michael-fassbender-telluride-film-festival-1201586996%2F&date=2016-09-04 |archive-date=2016-09-04 |dead-url=no}}</ref> [[Sasha Stone]], writing for ''[[TheWrap]]'', stated that Fassbender gives "a stunning knockout" performance as Jobs in a film that is "a kind of talk opera", which to some might seem to be "Sorkin overkill but the same could be said for the best of them: [[David Mamet]], [[Edward Albee]], [[Paddy Chayefsky]] and even [[William Shakespeare]]. Sorkin is not trying to do anything but write in his own style, thus this film and its exceptional dialogue leaves its mark as profoundly as Jobs himself left his."<ref name=stonerev>{{cite web |last=Stone |first=Sasha |url=http://www.thewrap.com/steve-jobs-telluride-review-michael-fassbender-is-stunning-in-breathtaking-relentless-biopic/ |title=''Steve Jobs'' Telluride Review: Michael Fassbender Is Stunning in Breathtaking, Relentless Biopic |accessdate=September 12, 2015 |date=September 5, 2015 |work=TheWrap |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.thewrap.com%2Fsteve-jobs-telluride-review-michael-fassbender-is-stunning-in-breathtaking-relentless-biopic%2F&date=2016-09-04 |archive-date=2016-09-04 |dead-url=no}}</ref> Eric Kohn of [[IndieWire]] gave the film a "B+", stating that "the cast vanishes into their parts...buried under makeup and a distinctive Polish accent, Winslet's chameleonesque transformation is bested only by Fassbender, whose vivid expressions and constant movement turn him into a physical marvel." He also noted that Boyle "drops his usual whirlwind editing style and instead develops an engrossing chamber piece."<ref name=iw>{{cite web|last=Kohn|first=Eric|url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/telluride-review-danny-boyles-steve-jobs-is-like-its-subject-flawed-but-fascinating-20150906|title=Telluride Review: Danny Boyle's ''Steve Jobs'' is Like Its Subject — Flawed But Fascinating|accessdate=September 6, 2015|date=September 6, 2015|work=[[IndieWire]]|archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.indiewire.com%2Farticle%2Ftelluride-review-danny-boyles-steve-jobs-is-like-its-subject-flawed-but-fascinating-20150906&date=2016-09-04|archive-date=2016-09-04|dead-url=no}}</ref>
Benjamin Lee of ''[[The Guardian]]'' gave the film three out of five stars, writing that "despite the film constantly informing you of just how incredibly important everything all is, it's disappointingly difficult to truly care about what's taking place." He blames Sorkin's "dominating" script, arguing that "the dialogue stifles" and that "the actors are tasked with trying to wrangle enough breathing space to offer up something of their own." He also feels that while it is "Boyle's best film for years," his direction "plays second fiddle" to a script that verges on a kind of "Apple-sponsored hero iWorship."<ref name=guarrev>{{cite web |last=Lee |first=Benjamin |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/sep/06/steve-jobs-movie-review-michael-fassbender-telluride |title=Steve Jobs review: Fassbender excels but iWorship required if you're to care |accessdate=September 12, 2015 |date=September 6, 2015 |work=The Guardian |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.theguardian.com%2Ffilm%2F2015%2Fsep%2F06%2Fsteve-jobs-movie-review-michael-fassbender-telluride&date=2016-09-04 |archive-date=2016-09-04 |dead-url=no}}</ref> [[Joe Nocera]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'', who knew Jobs well, took issue with "how little the film has to do with the flesh and blood Steve Jobs." Characterizing the movie as pure "fiction", he went on to say, "In ways both large and small, Sorkin − as well as Michael Fassbender, the actor who plays Jobs − has failed to capture him in any meaningful sense."<ref name=Nocera>{{cite news|last1=Nocera|first1=Joe|authorlink=Joe Nocera|title=Aaron Sorkin's ''Steve Jobs'' Con|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/13/opinion/aaron-sorkins-steve-jobs-con.html|accessdate=October 14, 2015|work=The New York Times|date=October 13, 2015|archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2015%2F10%2F13%2Fopinion%2Faaron-sorkins-steve-jobs-con.html&date=2016-09-04|archive-date=2016-09-04|dead-url=no}}</ref>
=== Historical accuracy === [[Danny Boyle]], the film's director, speaking on the creative liberties he took with portraying Steve Jobs said, "[it] was what [[Shakespeare]] used to do. He would take some of the facts about a man of power and he would guess at a lot of the rest and just gotten away at actually getting at the human in it. And that's what's wonderful about the writing I think, is that it acknowledges the people who disliked Steve Jobs, the people he hurt. But in the end, he brings it back to a very simple father-daughter relationship that he has to admit that he has made some of the most beautiful things in the world."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.slashfilm.com/danny-boyle-steve-jobs-interview/2/ |title=Interview: Director Danny Boyle Talks About The Making Of ''Steve Jobs''|last=Sciretta |first=Peter |work=[[/Film]] |date=October 15, 2015 |accessdate=November 18, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.slashfilm.com%2Fdanny-boyle-steve-jobs-interview%2F2%2F&date=2016-09-04 |archive-date=2016-09-04 |dead-url=no}}</ref>
[[John Sculley]] praised [[Jeff Daniels]]' portrayal of him, but claims the film misrepresented [[Apple Inc.|Apple]]'s success with the [[Macintosh|Mac]], and argues that Jobs was "much nicer" than depicted.<ref name="sculleymacrumors">{{cite web |url=http://www.macrumors.com/2015/10/06/john-sculley-on-steve-jobs-movie/ |title=John Sculley Talks Steve Jobs Movie, Impressed With Jeff Daniels' Portrayal of Him |last=Sumra |first=Husain |work=[[MacRumors]] |date=October 6, 2015 |accessdate=November 19, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.macrumors.com%2F2015%2F10%2F06%2Fjohn-sculley-on-steve-jobs-movie%2F&date=2016-09-04 |archive-date=2016-09-04 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref name="sculleywsj">{{cite web |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2015/10/06/john-sculley-on-steve-jobs-the-movie-the-man-and-his-own-role-in-the-drama/ |title=John Sculley on Steve Jobs: The Movie, the Man and His Own Role in the Drama |last=Chai |first=Barbara |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=October 6, 2015 |accessdate=November 19, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fblogs.wsj.com%2Fspeakeasy%2F2015%2F10%2F06%2Fjohn-sculley-on-steve-jobs-the-movie-the-man-and-his-own-role-in-the-drama%2F&date=2016-09-04 |archive-date=2016-09-04 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref name="sculleyfrance">{{cite web |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20151105-business-web-summit-dublin-john-sculley-apple-steve-jobs-film |title=Former Apple CEO: 'Steve Jobs was nicer than new film shows' |last=Carroll |first=Stephen |work=[[France 24]] |date=November 5, 2015 |accessdate=November 19, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.france24.com%2Fen%2F20151105-business-web-summit-dublin-john-sculley-apple-steve-jobs-film&date=2016-09-04 |archive-date=2016-09-04 |dead-url=no}}</ref> [[Bill Atkinson]] denounced the film as "not truthful at all. That wasn't his character, and the events didn't happen. You think of Jobs having a [[reality distortion field]]. I think of Aaron Sorkin as having ... a history distortion field". Atkinson said that "the only thing he got right in that movie" was the "spot on" depiction of Hoffman, including her accent and how she "tried to rein in Steve from ... making an ass of himself".<ref name="Tri247">{{Triangulation|247|[[Bill Atkinson]]}}</ref>
[[Steve Wozniak]] (who consulted with Sorkin before he had written the screenplay) commented on a trailer released on July 1, 2015 that he does not "talk that way... I would never accuse the graphical interface of being stolen. I never made comments to the effect that I had credit (genius) taken from me... The lines I heard spoken were not things I would say but carried the right message, at least partly... I felt a lot of the real Jobs in the trailer, although a bit exaggerated."<ref name=anyway>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-07-02/wozniak-says-scene-in-jobs-trailer-is-fiction-loves-it-anyway |title=Wozniak Says Scene in Jobs Trailer Is Fiction, Loves It Anyway |accessdate=July 2, 2015 |last=Sakoui |first=Anousha |date=July 1, 2015 |publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bloomberg.com%2Fnews%2Farticles%2F2015-07-02%2Fwozniak-says-scene-in-jobs-trailer-is-fiction-loves-it-anyway&date=2016-09-04 |archive-date=2016-09-04 |dead-url=no}}</ref> Wozniak did not ask to see the final script because he did not "think that would be appropriate... it is the creative work of the producer and writer and actors and director and others."<ref name=anyway /> He also noted that the trailer's reference to Jobs' initial rejection of his daughter [[Lisa Brennan-Jobs|Lisa]] evoked an emotional response: "It was hard on me, even being quiet, when Jobs refused to acknowledge his child when the money didn't matter, and I can almost cry remembering it."<ref name=anyway /> In September 2015, after seeing a rough cut of the film, Wozniak stated that he felt like he "was actually watching Steve Jobs and the others [....] not actors playing them, I give full credit to Danny Boyle and Aaron Sorkin for getting it so right."<ref name=filmpre>{{cite news |url=http://deadline.com/2015/09/steve-wozniak-says-steve-jobs-the-movie-gets-it-all-correct-1201516399/ |title=Steve Wozniak On ''Steve Jobs'': "I Felt Like I Was Actually Watching Him" – Telluride Film Festival |accessdate=September 7, 2015 |last=Hammond |first=Pete |date=September 6, 2015 |work=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fdeadline.com%2F2015%2F09%2Fsteve-wozniak-says-steve-jobs-the-movie-gets-it-all-correct-1201516399%2F&date=2016-09-04 |archive-date=2016-09-04 |dead-url=no}}</ref> In an interview with ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' on February 10, 2016, Wozniak claimed that the film's scenes between him and Jobs never occurred in reality. Wozniak specifically mentioned that he never requested Jobs to acknowledge the [[Apple II]] team onstage, as was shown in the movie. However, he added that Jobs did purportedly show a lack of respect towards the group. When asked about the accuracy of the film's portrayal of Jobs, Wozniak replied: "In real life, to real people, that's the way he could be, very sharp, (although) never quite as much as in the movie."<ref name="wozniaksfchron">{{cite web |url=http://www.sfchronicle.com/business/article/Woz-talks-Steve-Jobs-geek-culture-and-6824747.php |title='Woz' talks Steve Jobs, geek culture and Silicon Valley Comic Con |first=Benny |last=Evangelista |work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |date=February 10, 2016 |accessdate=February 18, 2016 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.sfchronicle.com%2Fbusiness%2Farticle%2FWoz-talks-Steve-Jobs-geek-culture-and-6824747.php&date=2016-09-04 |archive-date=2016-09-04 |dead-url=no}}</ref>
[[Edwin Catmull]], president of [[Pixar|Pixar Animation Studios]] and [[Walt Disney Animation Studios]], felt that Jobs would "be appalled" at his depiction in the film, arguing that he was a kinder person later in life than is portrayed in the picture. In an interview with ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'', Catmull commented, "When [Jobs] left Apple, he then entered into what really is the classic [[hero's journey]]: He's wandering in the wilderness, he's working with NeXT, it's not working. He's working with Pixar, we're failing. In that process, Steve learned some major lessons, and he changed. He became an empathetic person, [...] that aspect of the change of Steve was missed."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/disney-pixars-ed-catmull-good-840292 |title=Disney-Pixar's Ed Catmull on 'Good Dinosaur,' Female Directors and Why Steve Jobs Would Be "Appalled" by 'Steve Jobs' |date=November 20, 2015 |last=Belloni |first=Matthew |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |accessdate=November 21, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.hollywoodreporter.com%2Fnews%2Fdisney-pixars-ed-catmull-good-840292&date=2016-09-04 |archive-date=2016-09-04 |dead-url=no}}</ref>
In a ''[[Bloomberg West]]'' interview with [[Emily Chang (journalist)|Emily Chang]] on August 26, 2015, [[Andrea Cunningham|Andy Cunningham]] called it "a wonderful film.... It's an incredible character study of a really complex man. Aaron [Sorkin] and Danny Boyle did a fabulous job with it." Her portrayal by [[Sarah Snook]] was a "small role but professionally done."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Chang |first1=Emily |title=Andy Cunningham: What It Was Like Working With Steve Jobs |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2015-08-27/andy-cunningham-what-it-was-like-working-with-steve-jobs |website=Bloomberg |accessdate=August 27, 2015 |date=August 26, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bloomberg.com%2Fnews%2Fvideos%2F2015-08-27%2Fandy-cunningham-what-it-was-like-working-with-steve-jobs&date=2016-09-04 |archive-date=2016-09-04 |dead-url=no}}</ref> The film also portrays Andy as participating in the iMac launch, even though she was not working with Apple at that time.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Graham |first1=Jefferson |title=She was Steve Jobs' first publicist |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2015/09/06/she-steve-jobs-first-publicist/71787020/ |accessdate=September 12, 2015 |work=USA Today |date=September 6, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.usatoday.com%2Fstory%2Ftech%2F2015%2F09%2F06%2Fshe-steve-jobs-first-publicist%2F71787020%2F&date=2016-09-04 |archive-date=2016-09-04 |dead-url=no}}</ref> Journalist [[Walt Mossberg]] compared ''Steve Jobs'' to the [[Orson Welles]] film ''[[Citizen Kane]]'', which was loosely based on the life of [[William Randolph Hearst]]. Mossberg has stated that while both films are aesthetically well-developed, Welles created a fictional set of characters in order to clarify that his film was a work of fiction. In contrast, according to Mossberg (who knew Jobs for 14 years), Sorkin's decision to use real instead of fictional names detracts from the quality of a film which appears to be a biopic and yet is a work of fiction. Mossberg states that "the Steve Jobs portrayed in Sorkin's film isn't the man I knew. Sorkin chose to cherry-pick and exaggerate some of the worst aspects of Jobs' character, and to focus on a period of his career when he was young and immature [...] It would be as if you made a movie called ''[[JFK (film)|JFK]]'' almost entirely focused on Kennedy's womanizing and political rivalries, and said nothing about civil rights and the [[Cuban Missile Crisis]]. Sorkin opts to end his story just as Jobs is poised to both reel off an unprecedented string of world-changing products and to mature into a much broader, kinder manager and person."<ref name=mossberg>{{cite news |url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/10/21/9578921/steve-jobs-movie-review-walt-mossberg |title=Mossberg: The Steve Jobs I knew isn't in this movie |accessdate=October 22, 2015 |last=Mossberg |first=Walt |date=October 21, 2015 |work=[[The Verge]] |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.theverge.com%2F2015%2F10%2F21%2F9578921%2Fsteve-jobs-movie-review-walt-mossberg&date=2016-09-04 |archive-date=2016-09-04 |dead-url=no}}</ref>
=== Accolades === {{Main|List of accolades received by Steve Jobs (film)}} ''Steve Jobs'' has received dozens of industry and critics awards. The film garnered four [[Golden Globe Award]] nominations for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Drama|Best Actor]] for Fassbender, [[Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actress – Motion Picture|Best Supporting Actress]] for Winslet, [[Golden Globe Award for Best Screenplay|Best Screenplay]] for Sorkin, and [[Golden Globe Award for Best Original Score|Best Original Score]] for Pemberton. It won two, for both Winslet and Sorkin.<ref>{{cite web |last=Rosen |first=Christopher |title=Golden Globes 2016 winners list: Leonardo DiCaprio, The Revenant, Brie Larson & more |url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/01/10/golden-globes-2016-winners-list |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |date=January 10, 2016 |accessdate=January 11, 2016 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ew.com%2Farticle%2F2016%2F01%2F10%2Fgolden-globes-2016-winners-list&date=2016-09-04 |archive-date=2016-09-04 |dead-url=no}}</ref> On February 14, 2016, Winslet won the [[BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Supporting Role]].<ref>{{cite web |title=BAFTA Awards: ''The Revenant'' Wins Best Film, Actor, Director (FULL LIST) |url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/bafta-awards-winners-2016-complete-list-british-academy-film-television-1201706004/ |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |accessdate=February 14, 2016 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fvariety.com%2F2016%2Ffilm%2Fnews%2Fbafta-awards-winners-2016-complete-list-british-academy-film-television-1201706004%2F&date=2016-09-04 |archive-date=2016-09-04 |dead-url=no}}</ref> Both Fassbender and Winslet received [[Academy Award]] nominations for [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]] and [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Oscar Nominations 2015: Full List |url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/oscar-nominations-2015-full-list-academy-award-nominees-1201405517/ |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |accessdate=January 15, 2016 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fvariety.com%2F2015%2Ffilm%2Fnews%2Foscar-nominations-2015-full-list-academy-award-nominees-1201405517%2F&date=2016-09-04 |archive-date=2016-09-04 |dead-url=no}}</ref>
