{{Infobox book | name = The Functions of the Executive | author = [[Chester I. Barnard]] | image = The Functions of the Executive 1938 - Title Page of Eleventh Printing 1954.jpg | image_size = 200px | alt = Detail of title page of eleventh printing | caption = Detail of title page of eleventh printing | country = United States | language = English | publisher = [[Harvard University Press]] | pub_date = 1938 | media_type = Print ([[hardcover]]) | pages = xvi + 334 | oclc = 555075 | congress = HD31 .B36 }} '''''The Functions of the Executive''''' is a book by [[Chester I. Barnard]] (1886–1961) that presents a "theory of [[cooperation]] and [[organization]]" and "a study of the functions and of the methods of operation of [[Senior management|executives]] in formal organizations."{{cite book |title= The Functions of the Executive |last= Barnard |first= Chester I. |authorlink= Chester Barnard |year= 1938 |publisher= Harvard University Press |location= Cambridge, MA |oclc= 555075}}{{rp|xi-xii}} It was originally published in 1938; a Thirtieth Anniversary edition, published in 1968, is still in print.{{cite book |title= The Functions of the Executive |last= Barnard |first= Chester I. |authorlink= Chester Barnard |year= 1968 | edition = Thirtieth Anniversary |publisher= Harvard University Press |location= Cambridge, MA |isbn= 0674328000}}{{cite web |url= http://www.hup.harvard.edu/catalog.php?isbn=9780674328037 |title= The Functions of the Executive: 30th Anniversary Edition| publisher = Harvard University Press|accessdate= May 6, 2012}} The book is notable for its focus on how organizations actually operate, instead of previous approaches to organizations that emphasized "prescriptive principles."{{cite book | last = Rainey | first = Hal G.| authorlink = Hal G. Rainey |title = Understanding and Managing Public Organizations | publisher = Jossey-Bass| location = San Francisco| year = 1991 | edition = 1st| isbn = 1555423442}}{{rp|277}} It has been praised for being one of the first books to consider [[leadership]] from a social and psychological viewpoint.{{Cite book | last1 = Gabor | first1 = Andrea | title = The Capitalist Philosophers: the Geniuses of Modern Business – Their Lives, Times, and Ideas | year = 2000 | publisher = Times Business | location = New York | isbn = 0812928202}}{{rp|67}} An article in ''[[Public Administration Review]]'' reported that an informal advisory panel voted it one of the most influential books in [[public administration]] published between 1940 and 1990.{{cite journal|last1=Sherwood|first1=Frank P.|title=The Half-Century's 'Great Books' in Public Administration|journal=Public Administration Review|volume=50|issue=2|year=1990|pages=249–264|doi=10.2307/976872}} It was voted the second most influential [[management]] book of the 20th century in a poll of the Fellows of the [[Academy of Management]], behind ''[[The Principles of Scientific Management (monograph)|The Principles of Scientific Management]]'' by [[Frederick Winslow Taylor]].{{cite journal |last1= Bedeian |first1= Arthur G. |last2= Wren |first2= Daniel A.|author-link1= Arthur G. Bedeian|author-link2=Daniel A. Wren|date= Winter 2001 |title= Most Influential Management Books of the 20th Century |journal= Organizational Dynamics |volume=29 |issue=3 |pages= 221–225 |doi= 10.1016/S0090-2616(01)00022-5 | url = http://www.bus.lsu.edu/bedeian/articles/MostInfluentialBooks-OD2001.pdf}} ==Background== Barnard attended [[Harvard University]] between 1906 and 1909 where he majored in economics; however, he did not obtain a degree.{{Cite book | last1 = Wolf | first1 = William B. | title = The Basic Barnard: an Introduction to Chester I. Barnard and His Theories of Organization and Management | year = 1974 | publisher = [[Cornell University School of Industrial and Labor Relations|New York State School of Industrial and Labor Relations, Cornell University]] | location = Ithaca, NY | isbn = 0875460542 }}{{rp|7–8}} After rising through the ranks at [[AT&T Corporation]], Barnard became president of [[New Jersey Bell]] between 1927 and 1948.{{Cite book | last1 = Wolf | first1 = William B. | title = Conversations with Chester I. Barnard | year = 1973 | publisher = [[Cornell University School of Industrial and Labor Relations|New York State School of Industrial and Labor Relations, Cornell University]] | location = Ithaca, NY | isbn = 087546047X }}{{rp|56}} At New Jersey Bell, Barnard enjoyed "long hours of self-absorbed reflection and study."{{cite book | last = Hoopes | first = James | title = False Prophets: the Gurus Who Created Modern Management and Why Their Ideas are Bad for Business Today | publisher = Perseus Publishing | location = Cambridge, MA | year = 2003 | isbn = 0738207985 }}{{rp|171}} In 1936, Barnard gave a lecture at [[Princeton University]] entitled "Mind in Everyday Affairs."{{rp|19,92}} In the lecture, Barnard described the differences between "logical" and "non-logical" (i.e., "intuitional") mental processes.{{rp|302}} He encouraged the use of non-logical processes "for many conditions and purposes."{{rp|321}} Barnard had many contacts with Harvard officials, for example in relation to fundraising activities.{{Cite book | last1 = Wren | first1 = Daniel A. | last2 = Greenwood | first2 = Ronald G. | title = Management Innovators: the People and Ideas That Have Shaped Modern Business | year = 1998 | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = New York | isbn = 0195117050 | chapter = Chapter 8: Organizers | pages=155–169}}{{rp|165}} He and [[Lawrence Joseph Henderson]] were friends, and Henderson was a friend of [[Abbott Lawrence Lowell]], who had been president of Harvard and founder of the [[Lowell Institute]].{{rp|16–18}} Henderson suggested that Lowell invite Barnard to lecture at the Institute, and having read "Mind in Everyday Affairs" and another lecture by Barnard, Lowell did so.{{rp|18–21}} Barnard gave eight extemporaneous talks at the Lowell Institute in 1937 on the topic of "functions of the executive," and on the invitation of [[Dumas Malone]] (the director of [[Harvard University Press]] who met Barnard through [[Arthur W. Page]]), he revised the material from the talks to create the book.{{rp|vii}}{{rp|14–15}} Barnard's philosophy and thought processes in writing the book were characterized by [[humanism]], [[empiricism]], [[speculative philosophy]] (the interpretation of experience in a coherent framework), and analysis of the dichotomy of [[individualism]] and [[collectivism]].{{rp|46–59}} As cited in the book, his intellectual influences included [[Arthur F. Bentley]], [[Vilfredo Pareto]], Lawrence Joseph Henderson, [[Talcott Parsons]], [[W. H. R. Rivers]], [[Frederic Bartlett]], [[Elton Mayo]], [[Fritz Roethlisberger]], [[Mary Parker Follett]], [[James Harbord]], [[Alfred North Whitehead]], and [[John R. Commons]].{{rp|47,51,68,90,121,122,164,195,202}} His approach diverged from the "mechanistic conceptions" of Frederick Winslow Taylor and [[Henri Fayol]].{{rp|77}} ==Summary== ===Introduction to the Thirtieth Anniversary Edition=== In the 1968 edition, the Introduction by [[Kenneth R. Andrews]] evaluates the book and summarizes its place in the management literature. Andrews concludes that it is "the most thought-provoking book on organization and management ever written by a practicing executive."{{rp|xxi}} He contrasts ''Functions of the Executive'' with the "classical" approaches to organizations found in books such as ''Principles of Management'' by [[Harold Koontz]] and [[Cyril J. O'Donnell]].{{rp|xiv,xxii}} ===Preface=== Barnard gives an overview of his arguments in his Preface:{{rp|xi-xii}}
Formally this work is divided into four parts, but in a sense it consists of two short treatises. One is an exposition of a theory of cooperation and organization and constitutes the first half of the book. The second is a study of the functions and of the methods of operation of executives in formal organizations.
===Part I=== Part I is "Preliminary Considerations Concerning Cooperative Systems." In '''Chapter I''', "Introduction" (pages 3–7), Barnard notes that "formal organization is that kind of cooperation among men that is conscious, deliberate, purposeful," and that "successful cooperation in or by formal organizations is the abnormal, not the normal, condition."{{rp|4–5}}{{cite journal|last1=Keon|first1=Thomas L.|title=The Functions of the Executive by Chester I. Barnard |journal=Academy of Management Review|volume=11|issue=2|year=1986|pages=456–459|doi=10.2307/258476}}{{rp|457}}{{Cite book | last1 = Mahoney | first1 = Joseph T. | title = Economic Foundations of Strategy | year = 2005 | publisher = SAGE | location = Thousand Oaks, CA | isbn = 1-4129-0543-5 | chapter = Chapter 1: Behavioral Theory of the Firm | pages = 1–53 | url = http://www.sagepub.com/upm-data/5029_Mahoney_Chapter_1.pdf }}{{rp|3}} An individual may belong to many formal organizations, some of which may be short-lived. '''Chapter II''', "The Individual and Organization" (pages 8–15), states that individuals can be characterized in many ways (e.g., physical, social, psychological), but that for the purposes of discussion the book is concerned with the functional relationships among individuals in organizations. Barnard distinguishes between "effective" and "efficient" actions:
When a specific desired end is attained we shall say that the action is "effective." When the unsought consequences of the action are more important than the attainment of the desired end and are dissatisfactory, effective action, we shall say, is "inefficient." When the unsought consequences are unimportant or trivial, the action is "efficient."{{rp|19}}{{cite book | last = Callender | first = Guy | title = Efficiency and Management | publisher = Routledge | location = London and New York | year = 2009 | isbn = 9780415431804 }}{{rp|13}}
The remaining chapters in Part I elaborate on the relationships among people in a "cooperative system": * '''Chapter III''': "Physical and Biological Limitations in Cooperative Systems" (pages 22–37) * '''Chapter IV''': "Psychological and Social Factors in Systems of Cooperation" (pages 38–45) * '''Chapter V''': "The Principles of Cooperative Action" (pages 46–61) ===Part II=== The book's second part concerns "The Theory and Structure of Formal Organizations." Pages 65–81 contain '''Chapter VI''', "The Definition of Formal Organization." In the chapter, Barnard defines "formal organization" twice as "a system of consciously coordinated activities or forces of two or more persons."{{rp|73,81}}{{cite journal|last1= Copeland |first1= M. T. |title= The Job of an Executive |journal= Harvard Business Review |volume=18|date=Winter 1940|pages=159–172}}{{rp|149}} The chapter outlines how Barnard developed the definition and explains that the concept of organization is abstract. It specifies that a formal organization is part of a "cooperative system," a "complex of physical, biological, personal, and social components which are in a specific systematic relationship by reason of the cooperation of two or more persons for at least one definite end."{{rp|65}}{{rp|149}} '''Chapter VII''', "The Theory of Formal Organization" on pages 82–95, sets forth the three elements necessary for organizations: "(1) communication; (2) willingness to serve; and (3) common purpose."{{rp|82}}{{cite journal |last1= Scott |first1= William G. |last2= Mitchell |first2= Terence R. |date= Spring 1987|title= The Universal Barnard: His Macro Theories of Organization|journal= Public Administration Quarterly|volume=11 |issue=1 |pages= 34–58|jstor=40861334}}{{rp|40}} Barnard suggests both: (1) that an organization that cannot accomplish its purpose cannot survive, and (2) that an organization that accomplishes its purpose has no reason for existence. Therefore, organizations are constantly adopting new purposes.{{rp|91}} '''Chapter VIII''', "The Structure of Complex Formal Organizations" (pages 96–113), concerns the relationship of "superior" to "subordinate" organizations, the growth of organizations, and the relationship of small working "unit organizations" to "executive organizations" within complex formal organizations. In '''Chapter IX''', "Informal Organizations and Their Relation to Formal Organizations" (pages 114-123), Barnard states that formal organizations coexist with informal organizations (groups of people who interact with each other outside a formal organizational structure).{{rp|151}} Benefits of informal organizations include the promotion of communication, cohesiveness, and self-respect.{{rp|122}} ===Part III=== Part III is titled "The Elements of Formal Organizations" and begins with '''Chapter X''' (pages 127-138) about "The Bases and Kinds of Specializations." "The Economy of Incentives" is '''Chapter XI''' (pages 139-160). According to Barnard, "in all sorts of organizations the affording of adequate incentives becomes the most definitely emphasized task in their existence"{{rp|139}}{{rp|151}} Specific inducements range from "material inducements" to "ideal benefactions" (e.g., "[[pride of workmanship]]"), while "general incentives" include "personal comfort in social relations."{{rp|142–149}}{{rp|4}} Barnard's conclusions on incentives were drawn "almost entirely from observations… not from any reading."{{rp|28–29}} '''Chapter XII''', "The Theory of Authority" (pages 161-184) is notable for its summary of the conditions for authoritative communications, its explanation of "zone of indifference," and its distinction between "authority of position" and "authority of leadership." *Concerning authoritative communications, Barnard wrote:
A person can and will accept a communication as authoritative only when four conditions simultaneously obtain: (a) he can and does understand the communication; (b) ''at the time of his decision'' he believes that it is not inconsistent with the purpose of the organization; (c) ''at the time of his decision'', he believes it to be compatible with his personal interest as a whole; and (d) he is able mentally and physically to comply with it.{{rp|165}}{{rp|167–168}}{{rp|4–5}}
*Barnard discusses the concept of "zone of indifference," which is "perhaps the most well-known idea in the book," as follows:{{rp|5}}
...there exists a "zone of indifference" in each individual within which orders are acceptable without conscious questioning of their authority… The zone of indifference will be wider or narrower depending upon the degree to which the inducements exceed the burdens and sacrifices which determine the individual's adhesion to the organization. It follows that the range of orders that will be accepted will be very limited among those who are barely induced to contribute to the system.{{rp|167–169}}
*"Authority of position" is explained as occurring when people "impute authority to communications from superior positions… to a considerable extent independent of the personal ability of the incumbent of the position." In contrast, people with superior ability have "authority of leadership." When a person has both types of authority, the subordinate will "accept[] orders far outside the zone of indifference."{{rp|173–174}}{{rp|168}} In '''Chapter XIII''', "The Environment of Decision" (pages 185-199), Barnard contemplates how personal decision-making and organizational decision-making differ. He states "The fine art of executive decision consists in not deciding questions that are not now pertinent, in not deciding prematurely, in not making decision that cannot be made effective, and in not making decisions that others should make."{{rp|194}}{{rp|152}}{{cite journal|last1=Mahoney|first1=Joseph T.|title=The Relevance of Chester I. Barnard's Teachings to Contemporary Management Education: Communicating the Aesthetics of Management|journal=International Journal Organization Theory and Behavior|volume=5|issue=1-2|year=2002|pages=159–172|doi=10.1081/OTB-120004243|url= http://business.illinois.edu/josephm/publications/barnard%202002.pdf }}{{rp|165}} Part III concludes with '''Chapter XIV''', "The Theory of Opportunism" (pages 200-211). ===Part IV=== "The Functions of Organizations in Cooperative Systems" constitutes the final part of the book. It begins with '''Chapter XV''' ("The Executive Functions," pages 215-234) and '''Chapter XVI''' ("The Executive Process," pages 235-257). '''Chapter XVII''' on "The Nature of Executive Responsibility" (pages 258-284) discusses [[morality]]. Barnard observes that "cooperation, not leadership, is the creative process; but leadership is the indispensable fulminator of its forces."{{rp|259}}{{rp|166}} In turn, morality is critical to leadership: "organizations endure… in proportion to the breadth of the morality by which they are governed."{{rp|282}}{{rp|82}} The "Conclusion" ('''Chapter XVIII''', pages 285-296) highlights 16 major observations of the book and contemplates the relationship of science and art in management:
I believe that the expansion of cooperation and the development of the individual are mutually dependent realities, and that a due proportion or balance between them is a necessary condition of human welfare. Because it is subjective with respect both to a society as a whole and to the individual, what this proportion is I believe science cannot say. It is a question for philosophy and religion.{{rp|296}}{{rp|169}}
===Appendix=== The Appendix (pages 301-322) contains the text of Barnard's 1936 "Mind in Everyday Affairs" lecture. ==Criticisms== Criticisms of the book include: * It is "deadly… [with] little meaning today."{{cite journal|last1=Byrne|first1=John A. |title=A Classic Business Bookshelf|journal=BusinessWeek|date=March 5, 1990|url= http://www.businessweek.com/1989-94/pre94/b31481.htm }} * Its prose has been characterized as "difficult to read," "heavy," "turbid," and "atrocious."{{rp|2}}{{rp|174–175}}{{rp|150}} Even the Introduction to the Thirtieth Anniversary Edition notes the "ponderousness of Barnard's style."{{rp|xiii}} * The definition of "efficiency" in Chapter II is confusing.{{rp|13,194}} * The definition of "formal organization" in Chapter VI has been subject to considerable scrutiny. Although [[Hal G. Rainey]] acknowledged that the definition did distinguish Barnard from the "classical theorists" of management, he characterized it as "completely inadequate."{{rp|276}} [[Lyndall Urwick]] stated that "boy kisses girl" could qualify as an organization under Barnard's definition.{{rp|166}} * Statements such as "Personal aversions based upon racial, national, color, and class differences often seem distinctly pernicious; but on the whole they are, in the immediate sense, I believe, based upon a sound feeling of organization necessities" (page 147) have been assessed as "unenlightened" by today's standards.{{cite journal|last1=Dunphy|first1=Steven M.|last2=Hoopes|first2=James|title=Chester Barnard: Member of the "Élite"?|journal=Management Decision|volume=40|issue=10|year=2002|pages=1024–1028|doi=10.1108/00251740210452881}} * Barnard's ideas about authority in Chapter XII have been summarized as a "bottom-up power" theory that fails to acknowledge the reality that it is "sometimes the job of corporate leaders to use power to control, repress, and arrest the actions of their subordinates."{{rp|xxiv,175–177,273–277}} * A passage on page 319 ("…It is consequently necessary to say things in a form which is not correct from the standpoint of the speaker or writer…") has been interpreted as "advocating lying."{{cite book | last = Frederick | first = William Crittenden | title = Values, Nature, and Culture in the American Corporation | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = New York | year = 1995 | isbn = 0195357159 }}{{rp|130–131}} * Barnard did not write in any detail about the relationship between an organization and the customers of that organization.{{rp|458}} * The book does not consider how an executive of a corporation interacts with the board of directors or stockholders.{{rp|458}} * There is no significant mention of the education of staff (i.e., the executive's role as a teacher).{{rp|156–157}} ==Legacy== [[File:The Functions of the Executive - Cover of 30th Anniversary Edition 1968.jpg|thumb|right|Cover of 30th Anniversary Edition (1968)]]''The Functions of the Executive'' was to be the only book that Barnard ever wrote; however, he also wrote articles for journals, and collections of such articles have been published in books (e.g., the 1948 book ''Organization and Management'').{{rp|vii}} By 2010, the book had received over 8,000 citations in [[Google Scholar]].{{cite web |url= http://www.business.uiuc.edu/Working_Papers/papers/10-0102.pdf |title= Chester Barnard and the Systems Approach to Nurturing Organizations | publisher = [[University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign]], [[UIUC College of Business|College of Business]] | series= Working Paper 10-0102 |author1=Gabor, Andrea |author2=Joseph T. Mahoney |lastauthoramp=yes |year= 2010 |accessdate= May 6, 2012}}{{rp|1}} Among other works, the book influenced:{{rp|xvi-xvii}}{{rp|255}}{{rp|1}} * ''[[Administrative Behavior]]'' by [[Herbert A. Simon]] (1947).{{cite journal |last1= Mitchell |first1= Terence R. |last2= Scott |first2= William G. |date= Fall 1988|title= The Barnard-Simon Contribution: a Vanished Legacy|journal= Public Administration Quarterly|volume=12 |issue=3 |pages= 348–368|jstor=40861427}} In a 1988 interview, Simon was quoted as follows:{{cite journal |last1= Golembiewski |first1= Robert T. |year=1988 |title= Nobel Laureate Simon 'Looks Back': a Low-Frequency Mode |journal= Public Administration Quarterly |volume= 12|issue=3 |pages=275–300 |jstor= 40861423 |url=http://octopus.library.cmu.edu/cgi-bin/tiff2pdf/simon/box00069/fld05320/bdl0001/doc0001/simon.pdf }}
Of course I built squarely on Barnard, and have always felt deeply indebted to him; science is a cumulative endeavor. My general debt is expressed in the acknowledgements [p. xivii of the Second Edition]: "To Mr. Charles [sic] I. Barnard I owe a special debt: first, for his own book ''The Functions of the Executive''.…" In the book itself there are fourteen references to Barnard…. the notions of the contribution-inducement equilibrium, authority, and zone of acceptance were all derived from Barnard…. What I would now regard as the principal novelties in {{sic|''Administative''}} ''Behavior'' are the development of the concept of organizational identification…, the description of the decision process in terms of the processing of decision premises, and the bounded rationality notions…. Most of the rest is highly "Barnardian," and certainly even those "novel" ideas are in no way inconsistent with Barnard's view of organizations.
* ''The Human Group'' by [[George C. Homans]] (1950). * ''The Human Side of Enterprise'' by [[Douglas McGregor]] (1960). * ''New Patterns of Management'' by [[Rensis Likert]] (1961). * ''[[Behavioral theory of the firm|A Behavioral Theory of the Firm]]'' by [[Richard Cyert]] and [[James G. March]] (1963). * ''Markets and Hierarchies: Analysis and Antitrust Implications'' by [[Oliver E. Williamson]] (1975). Barnard's book also anticipated ''[[In Search of Excellence]]'' by [[Tom Peters]] and [[Robert H. Waterman, Jr.]], the concept of [[management by objectives]] that [[Peter Drucker]] popularized, the [[two-factor theory]] of [[Frederick Herzberg]], and [[Maslow's hierarchy of needs]].{{rp|79–80}} Examples of papers that have examined Barnard's "zones of indifference" concept include: * A 1994 textual analysis of Barnard's work.{{cite journal|last1=Golembiewski|first1=Robert T.|last2=Kuhnert|first2=Karl W.|title=Barnard on Authority and Zone of Indifference: Toward Perspectives on the Decline of Managerialism|journal=International Journal of Public Administration|volume=17|issue=6|year=1994|pages=1195–1238|doi=10.1080/01900699408524939}} * A 2000 psychological study that compared leaders' and followers' ratings of the followers' willingness to perform assignments from the leaders. Leaders rated the assignments as "less enjoyable, undesirable, more above the call of duty, and more likely to be resisted" than the followers reported.{{cite journal|last1=Barbuto|first1=John E.|title=Comparing Leaders' Ratings to Targets' Self-Reported Resistance to Task Assignments: an Extension of Chester Barnard's Zones of Indifference|journal=Psychological Reports|volume=86|issue=2|year=2000|pages=611–621|doi=10.2466/PR0.86.2.611-621}} * A 2001 qualitative study that examined how workplaces might have wider or narrower zones of indifference concerning the rights of employees infected with [[HIV]] under the [[Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990|Americans with Disabilities Act]].{{cite journal|last1= Slack |first1= James D. |title= Zones of Indifference and the American Workforce: the Case of Persons with HIV/AIDS|journal= Public Administration Quarterly|volume=25|issue=3|year=2001|pages=247–269|jstor=40861841}} As of 1961, the book had sold over 35,000 copies.{{rp|1}} As of 1982, the book had gone through 29 printings, and the Thirtieth Anniversary edition is still in print.{{cite journal|last1=Scott|first1=William G.|title=Barnard on the Nature of Elitist Responsibility|journal=Public Administration Review|volume=42|issue=3|year=1982|pages=197–201|doi=10.2307/976004}} It has been translated into many languages, including Arabic,{{rp|1}} Chinese,{{cite book | last = Barnard | first = Chester | title = Jing Li Ren Yuan De Zhi Neng| language= Chinese | publisher = Ji Xie Gong Ye Chu Ban She| location =Beijing | year = 2007| isbn = 9787111217978}} German,{{cite book | last = Barnard | first = Chester | title =Die Führung großer Organisationen | language= German | publisher = Girardet| location =Essen | year =1970 | oclc = 174906430}} Hebrew,{{cite book | last = Barnard | first = Chester | title = Tafḳide Ha-Menahel| language= Hebrew | publisher =Yaḥdaṿ | location =Tel Aviv | year =1970 | oclc = 19156236}} Italian,{{cite book | last = Barnard | first = Chester | title =Le Funzioni del Dirigente. Organizzazione e Direzione | language =Italian | publisher =Unione Tipografico-Editrice Torinese | location =Torino | year = | oclc = 11635002}} Japanese,{{cite book | last = Barnard | first = Chester | title =Keieisha no Yakuwari: Sono Shokunō to Soshiki | language= Japanese | publisher = Daiyamondosha| location = Tōkyō | year = 1956| oclc = 33677406 }} Polish,{{cite book | last = Barnard | first = Chester | title = Funkcje Kierownicze | language= Polish | publisher = Nowoczesnośc | location = Warszawa | year = 1997 | isbn = 8390181568 }} Portuguese,{{cite book | last = Barnard | first = Chester | title =Funções do Executivo | language= Portuguese | publisher = Atlas| location = São Paulo | year =1979 | oclc = 57022868}} Spanish,{{cite book | last = Barnard | first = Chester | title =Las Funciones de los Elementos Dirigentes | language= Spanish | publisher =Instituto de Estudios Políticos | location =Madrid | year =1959 | oclc = 28943262}} Swedish,{{cite book | last = Barnard | first = Chester | title = The Functions of the Executive: i Svensk Översättning | language= Swedish | publisher = Liber | location = Malmo | year = 2009 | isbn = 9789147089468 }} and Turkish.{{rp|1}} In 1988, the [[University of California, Berkeley]] held a series of seminars to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the book's publication; eight of the lectures became essays in a 1995 book edited by Oliver E. Williamson.{{Cite book | editor1-last = Williamson | editor1-first = Oliver E. | editor1-link= Oliver E. Williamson | title = Organization Theory: from Chester Barnard to the Present and Beyond | year = 1995 | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = New York | isbn = 0-19-509830-7 | pages = }} One issue of the ''International Journal of Public Administration'' in 1994 contained papers in honor of Barnard, many of which concerned the book.{{cite web |url= http://www.tandfonline.com/toc/lpad20/17/6|title= Volume 17, Issue 6, 1994 |work= International Journal of Public Administration|accessdate=May 6, 2012}} Joseph T. Mahoney of the [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]] wrote that ''The Functions of the Executive'' "is the most high-powered intellectual contribution to organization or economic theory ever written by a practicing manager" and that it appears to inspire students by conveying an "aesthetic feeling of managing."{{rp|5}}{{rp|160}} Although an informal advisory panel voted ''[[Administrative Behavior]]'' by Herbert Simon the most influential 1940–1990 book in academic public administration, "panel members had a tendency to associate Simon and Barnard," and one panel member wrote that Barnard's book was "the truly seminal work." ''The Functions of the Executive'' appeared in at least four lists of "best" or "most influential" management and business books between 2001 and 2011.{{cite book | last = Crainer | first = Stuart | author-link = Stuart Crainer| title = The Ultimate Business Library: the Greatest Books That Made Management | publisher = Capstone Pub | edition = 3rd| location = Oxford | year = 2003 | isbn = 1841120596 | chapter = Chester Barnard, ''The Functions of the Executive'' (1938) | pages = 15–17 }}{{cite web |url= http://www.businesspundit.com/25-best-business-books-ever/ |title= 25 Best Business Books Ever |author= Knufken, Drea |date= July 31, 2008 |work="Business Pundit" blog |accessdate=May 6, 2012}}{{Cite book | title = The Best Business Books Ever: the Most Influential Management Books You'll Never Have Time to Read | year = 2011 | publisher = Basic Books | location = New York | isbn = 9780465022366 | edition = 2nd | pages = 55–56 | chapter = ''The Functions of the Executive'' by Chester Barnard}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * {{cite journal|last1=Scott|first1=William G.|title=Barnard on the Nature of Elitist Responsibility|journal=Public Administration Review|volume=42|issue=3|year=1982|pages=197–201 |doi=10.2307/976004}} * {{Cite book | last1 = Scott | first1 = William G. | title = Chester I. Barnard and the Guardians of the Managerial State | year = 1992 | publisher = University of Kansas Press | location = Lawrence, KS | isbn = 0700605509 }} * {{cite journal|last1=Wolf|first1=William B.|title=Facts and Fictions Regarding Chester I. Barnard: a Review of William G . Scott's ''Chester I. Barnard and the Guardians of the Managerial State''|journal=International Journal of Public Administration|volume=18|issue=12|year=1995|pages=1859–1904|doi=10.1080/01900699508525079}} * {{cite journal|last1=McMahon|first1=Dave|last2=Carr|first2=Jon C.|title=The Contributions of Chester Barnard to Strategic Management Theory|journal=Journal of Management History|volume=5|issue=5|year=1999|pages=228–240|doi=10.1108/13552529910282222}} * {{cite journal|last1=Gehani|first1=R. Ray|title=Chester Barnard’s "Executive" and the Knowledge-Based Firm|journal=Management Decision|volume=40|issue=10|year=2002|pages=980–991|doi=10.1108/00251740210452845}} ==External links== * {{cite web |url= http://shelf1.library.cmu.edu/cgi-bin/tiff2pdf/simon/box00081/fld06520/bdl0003/doc0001/simon.pdf |title= The Functions of the Executive Revisited |author= Simon, Herbert A. |date= February 21, 1986 |accessdate=May 6, 2012}} (Paper published as: "Keieisha no Yakuwari Saihou."（「『経営者の役割』再訪」） Pages 3–17, translated into Japanese by T. Nishioka, in K. Kato & H. Meshino (Eds.), ''Barnard: Gendai Shakai to Soshiki Mondai'' [''Commemorative Papers for the Centenary of C.I. Barnard's Birth''].) * {{cite web |url= http://marthaholmes.wordpress.com/2010/08/31/the-functions-of-the-executive-a-moral-obligation-to-self-satisfaction/ |title= The Functions of the Executive: A Moral Obligation to Self-Satisfaction |author= Holmes, Martha |date= August 31, 2010 |work="The Experience of Ideas" blog |accessdate=May 6, 2012}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Functions of the Executive, The}} [[Category:1938 books]] [[Category:Business books]] [[Category:Public administration books]]

'''The World Challenge''' is a competition that was first hosted in 2005 by [[BBC]] and sponsored by [[Newsweek]] and [[Shell Oil Company|Shell]]. It accepts projects from around the world that deal with [[society|social]], [[Social environment|environmental]] and [[community]] issues and uses [[business]] methods to try to improve upon those issues in the world.
== The 2005 winners == *1st prize: [[Coconets]], from a project in the [[Philippines]] called [[Juboken Enterprises]] *2nd and 3rd prize: [[Reef rehab]] and [[I Do Foundation]]
==The 2006 winners == *1st prize: [[Elephant paper]] by [[Maximus (Sri Lanka)]] *2nd and 3rd prize: [[Cards from Africa]] and [[NGO Dalit]]
==The 2007 winners == *1st prize: [[T'ikapapa]], Potato Goldmine project in [[Peru]]. *2nd and 3rd prize: [[School for Success]] and [[Cooking without Gas]]
==The 2008 winners == *1st prize: [[Hashoo Foundation]], Plan Bee project in [[Pakistan]]. *2nd and 3rd prize: [[A Chance to Grow]] and [[School for Success]]
==The 2009 winners == *1st prize: [[Safe Bottle Lamp]] Foundation, A Bright Idea project in [[Sri Lanka]]. *2nd and 3rd prize: [[Nothing Wasted]] and [[Fungi Town]]
==The 2009 winners == *1st prize: [[AIDFI]], The Only Way is Up project in the [[Philippines]]. *2nd and 3rd prize: [[A Class Apart]] and [[Pass it on]]
==Sources== *[http://www.theworldchallenge.co.uk/ http://www.theworldchallenge.co.uk]

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox website | name = We the People | logo = File:We the People logo.png | logo_size = | logo_alt = We The People, Your voice in our government | logo_caption = Website logo (2011) | screenshot = File:We the People screenshot.jpg | collapsible = on | collapsetext = Screenshot | background = Gainsboro | screenshot_size = 250 px | screenshot_alt = | caption = Screenshot of website homepage (2017) | url = petitions.whitehouse.gov | commercial = No | type = Government site | registration = Required | language = English | num_users = | content_license = Public domain | programming_language = [[Drupal|Drupal 7]] | owner = U.S. Government | creator = [[Presidency of Barack Obama|Obama administration]] | editor = | launch_date = {{start date and age|2011|09|22|df=no}} | revenue = | alexa = | ip = 23.206.248.110 | issn = | oclc = | current_status = Operating | footnotes = }} '''We the People''', launched September 22, 2011,[http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2011/09/22/petition-white-house-we-people White House blog press release regarding the new "We the People" petitioning platform] was a section of the [[whitehouse.gov]] website (under [[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]]) for [[Right to petition|petitioning]] the administration's policy experts. Petitions that met a certain threshold of signatures were typically reviewed by Administration officials who prepared and issued official responses, however, this was not always the case. Criminal justice proceedings in the United States and other processes of the federal government are not subject to White House website petitions. We the People, rather, served as a public relations device for the Obama administration to provide a venue for citizens to express themselves. On August 23, 2012, the White House Director of Digital Strategy [[Macon Phillips]] released the source code for the platform.{{cite web|last=Phillips|first=Macon|title=We the Coders: Open-Sourcing We the People, the White House's Online Petitions System|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2012/08/23/open-sourcing-we-the-people|work=The White House Blog|accessdate=August 28, 2012}} The [[source code]] is available on [[GitHub]], and lists both public domain status as [[Copyright status of work by the U.S. government|a work of the U.S. federal government]] and licensing under the [[GPL v2]].{{cite web|title=We the People GitHub repository|url=https://github.com/WhiteHouse/petitions/blob/7.x-1.x/README.md#license|publisher=[[GitHub]]|accessdate=February 11, 2013}} On December 19, 2017, the [[Presidency of Donald Trump|Trump administration]] announced its intention to shut down the website and replace it with a "new platform would save taxpayers more than $1m a year." {{cite web|title=White House to 'temporarily' shut petition website|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-42409634|website=BBC|publisher=BBC|accessdate=19 December 2017}} As of May 2018, the site is operating as it was before it shut down. ==Overview== Users who wish to create a petition are required to register a free whitehouse.gov account. To sign a petition, users only need to provide their name and their email address, and they will receive an email with a link that they must click to confirm their signature. It is not necessary to have a whitehouse.gov account to sign a petition. ===Thresholds=== Under the Obama administration's rules, a petition had to reach 150 signatures ([[Dunbar's Number]]) within 30 days to be searchable on WhiteHouse.gov, according to [[Tom Cochran (technologist)|Tom Cochran]], former director of digital technology.{{cite web|first=Tom|last=Cochran|authorlink=Tom Cochran (technologist)|url=https://www.recode.net/2016/12/1/13765002/president-obama-digital-trump-administration-open-source|title=Farewell to Obama, our first digital president|publisher=Recode|date=December 1, 2016|accessdate=February 26, 2018}} It had to reach 100,000 signatures within 30 days to receive an official response.[https://wwws.whitehouse.gov/petitions#!/how-why/terms-participation ''We the People'' terms of participation page], whitehouse.gov The original threshold was set at 5,000 signatures on September 1, 2011,{{cite web|first=Macon|last=Phillips|authorlink=Macon Phillips|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2011/09/01/we-people-announcing-white-house-petitions-how-they-work|title=We the People: Announcing White House Petitions & How They Work|publisher=whitehouse.gov|date=September 1, 2011|accessdate=February 10, 2013}} was raised to 25,000 on October 3, 2011,{{cite web|first=Macon |last=Phillips|authorlink=Macon Phillips|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2011/10/03/good-problem-have-raising-signature-threshold-white-house-petitions|title=A good problem to have: Raising the signature threshold for White House petitions|publisher=whitehouse.gov|date=October 3, 2011|accessdate=August 13, 2015}} and raised again to 100,000 as of January 15, 2013.{{cite web|first=Macon|last=Phillips|authorlink=Macon Phillips|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2013/01/15/why-we-re-raising-signature-threshold-we-people|title=Why We're Raising the Signature Threshold for We the People|publisher=whitehouse.gov|date=January 15, 2013|accessdate=February 10, 2013}} The White House typically would not comment when a petition concerned an ongoing investigation.Eilperin, Juliet (June 10, 2013). [https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2013/06/10/white-house-petition-to-pardon-edward-snowden-gathers-steam/ "White House petition to pardon Edward Snowden gathers steam"], ''The Washington Post'' "It's unclear whether Trump's advisors will make a tradition of publicly responding to petitions from the American people," Dell Cameron wrote for the Daily Dot on the day that Trump was inaugurated,{{cite web|first=Dell|last=Cameron|url=http://www.dailydot.com/layer8/white-house-petitions-president-trump|title=Trump's team removes all old, pending 'We the People' petitions|publisher=Daily Dot|date=January 20, 2017|accessdate=January 28, 2017}} noting that the Trump administration that same day "archived" (that is, deactivated) all petitions in progress on the 'We the People' site. New petitions were created, but only two petitions—both created on Inauguration Day—soared above the 100,000-signature threshold within the Trump administration's first week, while other petitions created subsequently seemed not to count signatures at all.{{cite web|first=Tucker|last=Lieberman|url=http://disruptivedissertation.blogspot.com/2017/01/under-trump-administration-we-people.html|title=Under Trump administration, 'We the People' White House petition website is mysteriously broken|publisher=Disruptive Dissertation|date=January 28, 2017|accessdate=January 28, 2017}} The website was later fixed to count signatures but the Trump administration did not respond to any of the petitions until March 2018.[https://www.theverge.com/2017/3/22/15022050/donald-trump-white-house-petition-we-the-people-update Will Donald Trump keep the White House petition site alive?] The Verge, March 22, 2017
https://www.theverge.com/2018/3/20/17143536/white-house-we-the-people-online-petition-answers-back ==Notable petitions== ===Death Star=== In November 2012, a petition was created urging the government to create a [[Death Star]] as an economic stimulus and job creation measure gained more than 25,000 signatures, enough to qualify for an official response. The official (tongue-in-cheek) response released in January 2013{{cite web |last=Shawcross |first=Paul |title=This Isn't the Petition Response You're Looking For |url=https://www.wired.com/wiredscience/2013/01/white-house-death-star/ |date=January 11, 2013 |work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |accessdate=January 13, 2013}} noted that the cost of building a real Death Star has been estimated at $852 quadrillion and at current rates of steel production, would not be ready for more than 833,000 years.{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/white-house-rejects-death-star-petition-doomsday-devices-us-could-build-instead-1014682|title=White House Rejects Death Star Petition: Doomsday Devices US Could Build Instead|date=January 15, 2013|work=International Business Times|accessdate=March 12, 2015}} The response also noted that "the Administration does not support blowing up planets" and questions funding a weapon "with a fundamental flaw that can be exploited by a one-man starship" as reasons for denying the petition.{{cite web|title=It's a trap! Petition to build Death Star will spark White House response|url=http://cosmiclog.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/12/13/15889626-its-a-trap-petition-to-build-death-star-will-spark-white-house-response}}{{cite web|title=US shoots down Death Star superlaser petition |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20997144 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=January 12, 2013}} ===Newtown shooting=== Following the [[Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting|spree shooting in Newtown, Connecticut]] on December 14, 2012, a petition for new gun-control measures achieved 100,000 signatures within 24 hours. ===Cell phone unlocking bill=== In February 2013, a petition started by [[OpenSignal]] co-founder and digital rights activist [[Sina Khanifar]] reached the 100,000-signature threshold required for a response from the White House.{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2014/08/15/heres-how-cell-phone-unlocking-became-legal|title=Here's How Cell Phone Unlocking Became Legal|work=The White House|accessdate=March 12, 2015}} Two weeks later, the Obama administration issued a response urging the FCC and Congress to take and legalize [[cell phone unlocking]]. A year later, Congress passed the [[Unlocking Consumer Choice and Wireless Competition Act]], the first piece of legislation driven by an online petition.{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2014/08/01/answering-publics-call|title=Answering the Public's Call|work=The White House|accessdate=March 12, 2015}} The bill was signed into law by President Obama on August 1, 2014. ===Prosecute 47 senators under the Logan Act=== In March 2015, as the United States and the [[P5+1]] group were negotiating with [[Iran]] on an [[Comprehensive agreement on Iranian nuclear program|agreement to restrain Iran's nuclear program]], 47 Republican [[United States Senate|Senators]] sent an open letter to the leaders of Iran strongly suggesting that a future president or Congress could nullify any such agreement. This action was widely construed as deliberate interference with the negotiations, and possibly a violation of the [[Logan Act]].[https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/mar/13/republican-senators-wrote-iran-guilty-crime-maybe "Were 47 Republican senators who wrote to Iran guilty of a crime?"], Ben Jacobs, ''[[The Guardian]],'' March 13, 2015 In response, several similar petitions were posted on March 9, 2015. One petition, entitled ''"File charges against the 47 U.S. Senators in violation of the Logan Act in attempting to undermine a nuclear agreement"'', passed the 100,000-signature threshold within one day. The petition had reached the number 1 spot, garnering more than 320,000 signatures by April 8, 2015, more than three times the number of signatures required to qualify for a response from the White House. For a variety of reasons, however, pundits, news analysts and legal scholars are largely skeptical that the petition will receive a favorable response leading to the requested prosecutions.ABC News.com, [http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/iran-letter-165000-sign-petition-prosecute-gop-senators/story?id=29564985 / "Iran Letter: 165,000+ Sign Petition to Prosecute GOP Senators for Treason"], Katelyn Marmon, Retrieved March 12, 2015Bloomberg.com, [https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2015-03-12/can-231-445-people-who-want-tom-cotton-tried-for-treason-be-wrong-yes-/"Can 231,445 People Who Want Tom Cotton Tried for Treason Be Wrong?"], David Weigel, Retrieved March 12, 2015Huffington Post, [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/monica-bauer/the-logan-act-and-the-treason-meme-click-bait-for-liberals_b_6849040.html/ "The Logan Act and the Treason Meme: Click Bait for Liberals"], Monica Bauer, Retrieved March 12, 2015NPR.com, [https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2015/03/11/392323244/why-the-gop-iran-letter-is-spurring-debate-over-an-18th-century-law/ "Why The GOP Iran Letter Is Spurring Debate Over An 18th Century Law"], Miles Parks, Retrieved March 12, 2015 ===Trump taxes=== "Within hours"{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/01/20/politics/obama-white-house-website/index.html |title=What happened to Obama's White House website? |author=Tal Kopan| date=January 20, 2017| access-date=January 20, 2017}} of President [[Donald Trump]]'s [[Inauguration of Donald Trump|inauguration]] on January 20, 2017, two petitions had been started on the site. One, for the release of his taxes, "with all information needed to verify emoluments clause compliance" reached the 100,000 signature threshold within twenty-four hours.{{Cite news|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/316382-petition-demanding-trumps-tax-returns-gets-record-number-of|title=Petition for Trump's tax returns gets record number of signatures|last=Greenwood|first=Max|date=26 January 2017|work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|access-date=27 January 2017|via=}} Another, for the President to divest himself of his assets or put them in a blind trust, had some seventy-seven thousand. On January 22, Presidential aide [[Kellyanne Conway]] declared that the tax returns will not be released.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/22/us/politics/donald-trump-tax-returns.html?_r=0|title=Trump Won't Release His Tax Returns, a Top Aide Says|date=January 22, 2017|publisher=New York Times|last1=Davis|first1=Julie Hershfeld|accessdate=January 23, 2017}} On January 27, the petitions had over 385,000 and 119,000 signatures, respectively, with the former being a record number of signatures for any petition on the site. By the February 17 deadline to reach 100,000 signatures, it had exceeded one million signatures, making it the first petition on the site to do so.{{cite news|last1=Manning|first1=Allee|last2=Kelly|first2=Kaitlyn|title=One Million People Demand Trump's Tax Return, Smashing Petition Record|url=http://www.vocativ.com/403165/we-the-people-petition-white-house-trump-taxes/|accessdate=February 17, 2017|work=Vocativ|date=February 17, 2017}} ===[[Antifa (United States)|American Antifa]]=== In August 2017, a petition requesting that "AntiFa" be classified by the Pentagon as a terrorist organization was launched. The petition had over 100,000 signatures within three days. The final count before White House responded was 368,423. The originator of the "AntiFa" petition, who goes by the pseudonym "Microchip", remarked to ''[[Politico]]'' that getting conservatives to share and discuss the petition was the entire point, rather than prompting any concrete action by the government.{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/08/24/antifa-white-house-petition-trump-troll-241990|title=White House 'antifa' petition written by pro-Trump troll|last=Musgrave|first=Shawn|date=August 24, 2017|work=Politico|accessdate=August 25, 2017}} The White House responded to the petition, stating "Although Federal law provides a mechanism to designate and sanction ''foreign'' terrorist organizations and foreign state sponsors of terrorism, there is currently no analogous mechanism for formally designating ''domestic'' terrorist organizations. Nonetheless, law enforcement has many tools at its disposal to address violent individuals and groups." (emphasis added)https://www.theverge.com/2018/3/20/17143536/white-house-we-the-people-online-petition-answers-back ==Criticism== Concerns about the efficacy of We the People have been raised since before the first White House responses were published.Forbes.com, [https://www.forbes.com/sites/kashmirhill/2011/09/23/what-the-people-want-abolishment-of-the-tsa-and-marijuana-legalization/ "What The People Want: Abolishment of the TSA and Marijuana Legalization"], Kashmir Hill On August 13, 2013, the ''[[Washington Post]]'' website published an article about 30 petitions that had been left unanswered for an average of 240 days despite each having met the signature goals. The article refers to the website www.whpetitions.info for taking "its own tally and highlights petitions that have received enough signatures but have not received responses."WashingtonPost.com, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2013/08/13/here-are-the-30-questions-the-white-house-doesnt-want-to-answer/ "Here are the 30 questions the White House doesn’t seem to want to answer"], Andrea Peterson As of 16 October 2016, 323 White House petitions have met their signature thresholds. The White House has responded to 321 of them (99%) with an average response time of 117 days. Average waiting time so far for two unanswered petitions: 23 days, according to whpetitions.info.[http://whpetitions.info/ whpetitions.info] The total number of petitions created and percent that have reached an actionable level beyond a response are unable to be determined at this time. Criticism has been directed{{by whom|date=February 2015}} at the choice of administration official to answer the petitions regarding the legalization of marijuana. [[Gil Kerlikowske]], the Director of the [[Office of National Drug Control Policy]], was chosen to craft the administration's response.whitehouse.gov, [https://wwws.whitehouse.gov/petitions#!/response/what-we-have-say-about-legalizing-marijuana We The People petition response, What We Have to Say About Legalizing Marijuana], Gil Kerlikowske The criticism stems from the Office of National Drug Control Policy Reauthorization Act of 1998, which states that the Director must oppose all attempts to legalize the use of illicit drugs in any form.Office of National Drug Control Policy Reauthorization Act of 1998, [http://www.whitehouse.gov/ondcp/reauthorization-act Title VII Sec. 704(b)(12)]redbook.gao.gov, [http://redbook.gao.gov/17/fl0083064.php Application of Anti-Lobbying Laws to the Office of National Drug Control Policy's Open Letter to State Level Prosecutors], B-301022, March 10, 2004, Anthony H. Gamboa Other discussions of We the People have focused on its technical glitches,''The Huffington Post'', [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jh-snider/we-the-people-petition-website_b_1062883.html/ The Case of the Missing White House Petition], October 31, 2011, J.H. Snider democratic rationale,''The Huffington Post'', [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jh-snider/what-is-the-democratic-fu_b_1018865.html/ What Is the Democratic Function of the White House's We The People Petition Website?], October 20, 2011, J.H. Snider and political dilemmas.''The Huffington Post'', [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jh-snider/we-the-people-petitions_b_1004466.html/ The White House's New We the People Petition Website], October 11, 2011, J.H. Snider There is criticism about the willingness of the administration to answer petitions that meet the threshold for response, when several qualifying petitions have been unanswered for months or years.{{cite web |author=Josh Feldman |date=April 2, 2014|url=http://www.mediaite.com/online/new-white-house-petition-demands-the-white-house-actually-answer-white-house-petitions/ |title=New White House Petition Demands the White House Actually Answer White House Petitions |publisher=MediaIte}} In addition, the [[Digital divide in the United States|digital divide]] means that poor communities will have difficulty participating equally in We The People.''New Statesman'', [http://www.newstatesman.com/blogs/voices/2012/04/britains-other-islanders-petition-white-house/ Britain's Other Islanders Petition the White House], April 3, 2012, Sean Carey During the first weeks of the presidency of Donald Trump, ''[[The Independent]]'' and ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' reported that many popular petitions did not appear to be receiving any signatures. Additionally, certain URLs to the petitions led to error pages.{{cite news|last1=Hooton|first1=Christopher|title=White House petition to save arts funding not registering signatures|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/president-donald-trump-arts-funding-nea-neh-cpb-prs-npr-petition-white-house-a7541631.html|accessdate=January 30, 2017|work=The Independent|date=January 23, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=PenzeyMoog|first1=Caitlin|title=White House petitions are basically turned off|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/white-house-petitions-are-basically-turned-249143|accessdate=January 30, 2017|work=The A.V. Club|date=January 26, 2017}} Macon Phillips, the man behind ''We the People'', told ''[[BuzzFeed|BuzzFeed News]]'' that the issue stemmed from issues with its [[Cache (computing)|cache]]. He also thought that Trump's administration "is still trying to get their heads around how it works".{{cite news|last1=Montgomery|first1=Blake|title=No, Signatures On The White House Petition Site Aren't Intentionally Frozen|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/blakemontgomery/signatures-on-the-white-house-nea-petition-site|accessdate=January 31, 2017|work=BuzzFeed|date=January 27, 2017|language=en}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Portal|Government of the United States}} * [https://petitions.whitehouse.gov/about Official About page] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MdcotOjqnVI Instruction video] * [https://github.com/WhiteHouse/petitions Source code] [[Category:Computer-related introductions in 2011]] [[Category:Government-owned websites]] [[Category:Online petitions]] [[Category:Presidency of the United States]] [[Category:Public consultations]] [[Category:Public-domain software with source code]] [[Category:Free software]]

'''Yukihiro Kayama''' (加山幸浩)
Born in Tokyo, 1939 Yukihiro Kayama is a prominent Japanese technologist, entrepreneur and venture capitalist. For 36 years he worked for Mitsubishi Corporation where he rose to become division head for technology. During his time there he was responsible for returning more than 200 billion yen (more than two billion US dollars) from a seed capital of less than 10M USD. This was mainly with early-stage/charter investments in companies such as [[Piri]],Piri were bought by SDLI who in turn were later bought by JDSU. SDLI acquires PIRI: {{cite web|url=http://www.convergedigest.com/daily/v7/v7n092.htm#SDL%20to%20Acquire%20Photonic%20Integration%20Research%20for%20$1.%20Billion |title=Archived copy |accessdate=November 25, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100223013606/http://www.convergedigest.com/Daily/v7/v7n092.htm |archivedate=February 23, 2010 }}JDSU acquires SDLI: http://www.jdsu.com/news/news-releases/2001/jds-uniphase-and-sdl-merger-completed-sale-of-zurich-subsidiary-to-nortel-networks-completed.html [[VeriSign]], and NetOne Systems. Kayama was also an early adopter of Sun’s Java programming language and was instrumental in getting it into the Mitsubishi Motors division. Upon retiring from Mitsubishi at the age of 59, he founded his own company EC-One{{cite web|url=http://www.ec-one.com/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=November 25, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091212045335/http://www.ec-one.com/ |archivedate=December 12, 2009 }} which was the first purely Java systems integrator in Japan. EC-One listed on the JASDAQ in 2002. He retired from EC-One in 2005 and founded his own incubator/venture capital firm Fit-One Holdings. He serves on the boards of GuardTime, MonstarLab, and Data Applications, and is advisor to China Seed Ventures (CSV). One of the most respected observers of technology not only globally but especially for Japan, [[Joi Ito]], believes that Kayama’s ability to support [[disruptive technology|disruptive technologies]] before anyone else sees them makes him a man to watch. "Mr. Kayama is a unique guy with a deep understanding of technology. I think he is one of the few senior technology-focused people who is very successful and has multiple, multimillion-dollar home runs under his belt. I look forward to working on something with him soon." http://joi.ito.com/weblog/2000/09/ Ito is one of the founding shareholders of Guardtime and eventually got his wish when Kayama joined [[Guardtime]] as Chairman in 2009. He has a master's degree in Engineering from [[Nihon University]] and is married with two children. ==References== {{DEFAULTSORT:Kayama, Yukihiro}} [[Category:1939 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Japanese businesspeople]] [[Category:Nihon University alumni]] [[Category:Venture capitalists]]

{{small|([[Master of Business|Master of Business Science]])}} | occupation = [[Economist]] | years_active = 2005 — present | nationality = Malawian | ethnicity = | citizenship = [[Malawi]]an | residence = [[Johannesburg]], [[South Africa]] | known_for = Economic analysis and forecasting | networth = | home_town = | title = Sub-Saharan Africa Economist
[[Renaissance Capital (Russian company)|Renaissance Capital]] | spouse = | religion = }} '''Yvonne Mhango''' is a [[Malawi|Malawian]] [[economist]]. She is the economist for [[Sub-Saharan Africa]] at [[Renaissance Capital (Russian company)|Renaissance Capital]].{{cite web| accessdate=4 October 2016| url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Strong-shilling-hurting-Kenya-exports-in-region/539552-3403804-obiwqmz/index.html | title=Strong shilling hurting Kenya’s exports in region | date=3 October 2016 | first=Charles |last=Mwaniki | newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] | location=Nairobi}}{{cite web| date=4 October 2016 | url=https://research.rencap.com/eng/whoarewe.asp?authorID=246 |title=Renaissance Capital : Our Team - Yvonne Mhango |accessdate=4 October 2016 | publisher=[[Renaissance Capital (Russian company)|Renaissance Capital Research]] (Rencap Research)| author=Rencap Research}} ==Background and education== She attended [[Saint Andrews International High School]] in [[Blantyre]], Malawi, where she studied Mathematics, Geography and Economics at A-Level, from 1996 until 1998. She was then admitted to the [[University of Cape Town]] in 1999, graduating with a [[Bachelor of Business Science]] in 2002. From 2003 until 2004, she studied at the same university, graduating with a [[Master of Business|Master of Business Science]].{{cite web| url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/yvonne-mhango-10332410 | title=Academic & Career Profile of Yvonne Mhango |accessdate=4 October 2016 | date=4 October 2016 | publisher=Linkedin.com | author=Yvonne Mhango}} ==Career== From 2005 until 2008, Mhango was an economist at [[Standard Bank of South Africa]]. In June 2008, she became the head of economic research for Africa at Standard Bank, serving in that capacity until November 2010. Since November 2010, she has been the economist for sub-Saharan Africa at Renaissance Capital. In June 2016, following the [[Central Bank of Nigeria]]'s decision to allow the niara to freely float against other currencies, Mhango said that floating the naira freely would “release a pressure valve for the economy”, which would in turn “see the economy beginning to thaw and green shoots emerge possibly as soon as a year from now”.{{cite web| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2016/06/20/nigerias-naira-plunges-30pc-after-central-bank-gives-up-on-dolla/ | title=Nigeria’s naira plunges 30 percent after central bank gives up on dollar peg | accessdate=12 November 2016 | date=20 June 2016 | last=Spence | first=Peter |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] | location=London}} Mhango, with others had correctly predicted such a devaluation in the naira, following the flotation of the [[Kazakhstan]] currency in August 2015.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-08-21/africa-is-running-out-of-options-as-china-to-kazakhstan-devalue | title=Africa Running Out of Options as China to Kazakhstan Devalue | last=Paul Wallace |first=and Rene Vollgraaff | date=21 August 2015 | publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg News]] |accessdate=12 November 2016}} In October 2016, Mhango and other economists at Renaissance Capital said that the Kenya Shilling was about 20 percent overvalued and that this was hurting [[Kenya]]'s exports to other countries in the region.{{cite web| url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Strong-shilling-hurting-Kenya-exports-in-region/539552-3403804-obiwqmz/ | title=Strong shilling hurting Kenya’s exports in region | accessdate=12 November 2016 |last=Mwaniki|location=Nairobi |newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] |first=Charles| date=3 October 2016}} ==Other achievements== Yvonne Mhango is a co-author of the book [http://www.fastestbillion.com/ The Fastest Billion], about Africa's economic revolution.{{cite web| url=http://www.fastestbillion.com/ |title=The Fastest Billion | authors=Charles Robertson, Yvonne Mhango, Michael Moran, Arnold Meyer and Nothando Ndebele |accessdate=4 October 2016| publisher= Renaissance Capital}} ==See also== * [[List of banks in South Africa]] ==References== {{reflist}} slower by Yvonne Mhango on 15 July 2014] {{DEFAULTSORT:Mhango, Yvonne}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:Malawian businesspeople]] [[Category:University of Cape Town
